{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16200,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cissus verticillata prefers consistent moisture but should not be overwatered, as this can lead to root rot. It’s ideal to water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. During warmer months, this could mean watering once a week, but in cooler months, the watering frequency can be reduced. Always ensure that your plant has drainage in its pot to prevent standing water, which can harm the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cissus verticillata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sun exposure, especially during the hottest parts of the day, can scorch the leaves, leading to discoloration or damage. If placed indoors, a spot near an east or west-facing window where it can receive filtered light is ideal. In lower light conditions, the plant may grow more slowly. Ensure that it’s not in deep shade, as this can weaken the plant and result in sparse growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is an important aspect of maintaining Cissus verticillata, especially since it can grow quite vigorously. Regularly trim back long, unruly stems to encourage bushier growth and shape the plant as desired. Pruning can also help to maintain its form and manage its size. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased leaves and stems throughout the growing season. This not only improves appearance but also prevents the spread of potential diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Possum grape","description":"Cissus verticillata, the princess vine or seasonvine, is an evergreen perennial vine in the grapevine family Vitaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Possum grape"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cissus verticillata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17194,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Xanthomendoza hasseana, a type of lichen, is generally low-maintenance when it comes to watering because it primarily absorbs moisture and nutrients from the air. In a controlled environment like indoors or a lichenarium, this species should be misted occasionally, especially if conditions are particularly dry. Ensure the environment is humid enough to promote healthy growth, but avoid soaking the lichen directly in water, as this can lead to rot. In nature, this lichen persists in arid regions, so mimicking those intermittent natural hydration conditions is key."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Xanthomendoza hasseana thrives in environments with indirect, moderate sunlight. It is accustomed to more sunlit areas when found in the wild, often on rocks or sunny tree bark, so it can handle brighter light conditions. However, direct sunlight, particularly for extended periods, should be avoided as it may lead to desiccation or sunburn. If keeping it indoors or under glass, ensure it has ample filtered sunlight, simulating its natural habitat without exposing it to harsh, direct rays that could damage the lichen."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Xanthomendoza hasseana as lichens grow slowly and have a self-maintaining structure. However, if you're cultivating it in a curate space like a terrarium and notice any unsightly dead or discolored patches, you may gently remove those sections with sterilized tools to prevent decay. It is important to handle with care, as lichens can be fragile. Pruning might encourage a more aesthetically pleasing appearance or help in renewing the growth in cultivated environments."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Poplar Sunburst Lichen","description":"Gallowayella hasseana, the poplar sunburst lichen, is a species of corticolous (bark-dwelling), crustose lichen in the family Teloschistaceae. It occurs in North America.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Poplar Sunburst Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Fragmentation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Xanthomendoza hasseana"],"soil":["Rocky","Gravelly","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17683,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polygonatum verticillatum, commonly known as Whorled Solomon's-seal, prefers consistently moist soil, but not overly waterlogged. It's important to water the plant regularly, especially during the growing season, ensuring the soil remains damp. However, allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. In hot climates or dry spells, you might need to water more frequently. Reduce watering in the fall when the plant begins to enter dormancy. Using mulch can help retain moisture and provide a conducive environment for its growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polygonatum verticillatum thrives in partial to full shade environments, making it ideal for woodland garden settings. It can tolerate morning sun but prefers to be shielded from the harsh afternoon sunlight as excessive sun can damage the leaves. In deep shade, it may grow a bit spindly, so a balance of dappled light works best. If planted in areas with too much sun, ensure it receives adequate moisture to prevent drying out. For optimal growth, mimic its natural understory habitat by providing filtered light through tree canopies or nearby larger plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polygonatum verticillatum is generally minimal. In early spring, remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems to encourage healthy growth. After flowering, you can deadhead spent blooms to keep the garden tidy, although this isn't necessary for the plant's health. In late autumn or early winter, when the foliage has completely died back, cut the stems down to the ground. This will help the plant conserve energy over the winter and encourage robust growth in the spring. Regular cleaning out of dead foliage prevents pests and diseases from overwintering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Whorled Solomon's-seal","description":"Polygonatum verticillatum or whorled Solomon's-seal is a plant species of the genus Polygonatum. It is widespread in Europe and also in China and the Himalayas though not reported from large sections of western and Central Asia in between those two ranges.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Europe"],"other_name":["Whorled Solomon's-seal"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Rhizome division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Polygonatum verticillatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16984,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Selaginella lepidophylla, known as the \"Resurrection Plant,\" requires minimal watering due to its ability to thrive in extremely dry conditions. During active growth, water it every 1-2 weeks, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. This plant can tolerate dry spells by curling up and entering a dormant state, \"resurrecting\" when moisture returns. Avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. You can either mist it lightly or soak the plant in water for an hour, and then let it drain completely. Adjust frequency based on the environment's humidity and temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Selaginella lepidophylla thrives in indirect or low-light conditions. It is well-suited for indoor environments where it can receive filtered light or partial shade, such as from a north or east-facing window. Direct sunlight can cause the fronds to scorch and lead to dehydration, so it is best to avoid placing the plant in such conditions. If placed outdoors, choose a shady spot where it gets dappled sunlight. The plant can handle a range of light conditions but prefers those mimicking its natural desert floor habitat with indirect sunlight and consistently warm temperatures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Selaginella lepidophylla is generally minimal. Since it grows slowly and doesn't typically develop unruly growth, the primary reason for pruning is to remove any dead or discolored fronds. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to snip off these parts at their base to prevent disease and maintain the plant's aesthetic. Pruning can also help encourage new growth, though it's not always necessary. Inspect the plant regularly and remove any debris or dead foliage to ensure good air circulation around the plant and to promote a healthy growing environment."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"resurrection plant","description":"Selaginella lepidophylla (syn. Lycopodium lepidophyllum) is a species of desert plant in the spikemoss family (Selaginellaceae). S. lepidophylla is noted for its ability to survive almost complete desiccation; during dry weather in its native habitat, its stems curl into a tight ball and uncurl only when exposed to moisture. The outer stems of Selaginella lepidophylla bend into circular rings in a relatively short period of desiccation, whereas inner stems curl slowly into spirals due to the...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Chihuahuan Desert","USA","Mexico"],"other_name":["resurrection plant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Selaginella lepidophylla"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16695,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nephrolepis biserrata, commonly known as the Giant Sword Fern, prefers consistently moist soil. It is essential to keep the soil evenly moist but not soggy. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. During winter months, slightly reduce watering since the plant's growth slows down. It's important to use room temperature water to avoid shocking the roots, and where possible, use distilled water or rainwater as tap water can contain minerals that may harm the plant over time."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Giant Sword Fern thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, making it an excellent choice for indoor settings or shaded outdoor areas. Avoid direct sunlight as it can scorch the leaves, leading to browning and damage. If placing the plant indoors, choose a spot near an east or north-facing window where it can receive soft, filtered light. In outdoor gardens, position the plant in a location that receives dappled sunlight or partial shade. Consistent exposure to indirect light will ensure lush, vigorous growth and rich green foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nephrolepis biserrata involves removing any dead, damaged, or yellowing fronds to encourage healthy growth and maintain aesthetic appeal. Fronds should be cut close to the base using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. Regular pruning can help prevent disease and maintain good airflow around the plant. Prune dead fronds as they appear throughout the year, but limit extensive pruning to the spring, when the plant is actively growing. Regularly cleaning debris and dead fronds also helps in landscape settings, especially in outdoor environments."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Broad Sword Fern","description":"Nephrolepis biserrata (giant swordfern, 长叶肾蕨) is a tropical fern, endemic to Florida, Mexico, the West Indies, Central America, South America, Africa, and southeast Asia. Its stipes are grayish brown and 10–50 cm × about 4 mm in size, with brownish-green, papery lamina that are 14–30 cm wide × 0.7–2 m in length.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central America","South America","West Indies"],"other_name":["Broad Sword Fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Spores","Division"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Nephrolepis biserrata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17982,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cerinthe minor, or lesser honeywort, prefers consistent moisture in its soil but should never be waterlogged. It's important to let the top layer of soil dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During its active growing season in spring and early summer, you may need to water more frequently, especially in hotter climates. In contrast, reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing. Always consider the drainage of the soil and the climate of your area when determining a watering schedule."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"For optimal growth, Cerinthe minor thrives in full to partial sun. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day. However, in regions with scorching summers, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from intense heat and prevent leaf scorch. If grown in overly shady conditions, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Observing the plant's reaction to its environment and modifying its light exposure can help maintain its health and encourage prolific blooming throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cerinthe minor is relatively straightforward. Cut back any spent flower stems after blooming to encourage additional flowering and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. This can also prevent unwanted self-seeding if you prefer to control its spread. In early spring, clean up any dead or damaged foliage from the winter months. If the plant becomes untidy or overgrown, you can trim it back lightly to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Regular removal of dead leaves will also help maintain its overall health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Lesser Honeywort","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Lesser Honeywort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Cerinthe minor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17387,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acmella repens, commonly known as the creeping spotflower, prefers consistently moist soil, as it naturally grows near water bodies. It is important to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry. During hot weather or intense sun exposure, you might need to increase the frequency of watering to prevent the soil from drying out completely. Be cautious of overwatering, particularly if it is growing in containers, to avoid root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acmella repens thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to encourage robust growth and prolific blooming. However, it can tolerate some shade, particularly in hot climates, where dappled sunlight or afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window with plenty of light. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even light exposure and balanced growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acmella repens involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged stems to encourage bushier growth and prolong the blooming period. Regularly pinching off the tips of the stems can also promote a fuller appearance. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease. Avoid heavy pruning during the plant’s flowering period, as this can reduce the number of blooms. Regularly monitor and trim any excessive or untidy growth as needed to maintain the desired shape and size."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Oppositeleaf Spotflower","description":"Acmella repens is a North American species of flowering plants in the sunflower family. The plant is native to the southeastern and south-central United States, primarily in the coastal plain from Texas to North Carolina and in the lower Mississippi Valley from Missouri to Louisiana. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16892,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus laceyi, also known as Lacey oak, is quite drought-tolerant once established. Water it deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. During its first few years, regular watering is crucial, especially in dry periods. Aim to water the plant approximately once a week during dry spells. For mature trees, ensure they're watered once every 2-3 weeks during extreme drought conditions, adapting to the prevailing weather and soil conditions. Always allow the soil to dry out between watering to prevent root rot, ensuring a healthy and robust growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus laceyi thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and development. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight may result in slower growth and reduced foliage density. This oak is well-suited for hot climates, as it can withstand intense sunlight once established. When planting, choose a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day, enhancing its growth and vitality. Providing the right amount of sunlight will ensure a healthy, vibrant tree."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus laceyi is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree's health. Light pruning can improve structural integrity and air circulation. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the tree. Focus on removing crossed branches or those that disrupt the natural shape of the tree. Use clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts that the tree can easily heal. Monitor the plant for signs of too much or too little sunlight and adjust its placement accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hypericum stragulum is best done in early spring before new growth begins, or immediately after flowering to encourage a tidy shape and promote blooms. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged stems to keep the plant healthy. Light pruning can be done to shape the plant, but avoid cutting back more than one-third of the overall plant. This species may benefit from occasional hard pruning to stimulate vigorous growth, particularly if it has become leggy. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to make cuts just above a leaf node for optimal results."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"low St. John's wort","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["low St. John's wort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hypericum stragulum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16497,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Houstonia serpyllifolia, commonly known as Thymeleaf Bluet, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its active growing season in spring and early summer. It thrives in naturalistic settings like woodland gardens or rocky slopes where it can benefit from regular rainfall. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. This helps to prevent root rot, a condition to which many Houstonia species can be prone if kept too wet. Take care not to water directly on the leaves to reduce the risk of fungal disease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thymeleaf Bluet thrives best in locations with partial to full sun exposure. It enjoys morning sun and can tolerate some light shade, especially in hotter climates, to prevent the foliage from wilting. A site that provides about 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day is ideal. In areas with intense afternoon sun, providing some dappled shade can help maintain its vibrant foliage and beautiful blooms. If grown in too much shade, the blooming can be reduced, and the plant may become leggy, striving for more light. Adjust its location accordingly to optimize its growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Houstonia serpyllifolia is generally minimal as it is a small, low-growing perennial. Pinch back spent flowers to encourage more blooms and to maintain a tidier appearance. At the end of the flowering season, you can trim back any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth in the following season. Regularly inspect the plant for signs of disease or insect damage and remove affected parts as necessary. This light maintenance encourages vigorous growth and a healthier plant overall, while also controlling the shape and size for aesthetic purposes in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Thyme-leaved Bluet","description":"Houstonia serpyllifolia, (common names creeping bluet, mountain bluet, thymeleaf bluet, Appalachian bluet) is a plant species in the Rubiaceae. It is native to the eastern United States, primarily the Appalachian Mountains. The name \"serpyllifolia\" alludes to the resemblance between this plant and the culinary herb wild thyme, Thymus serpyllum. Houstonia serpyllifolia grows in Pennsylvania, Maryland, West Virginia, western Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee, and northeastern Georgia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Thyme-leaved Bluet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Houstonia serpyllifolia"],"soil":["Acidic","Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, maintaining its health may involve occasionally tidying up its appearance by gently removing any brown or dead tips with scissors. Adjust the light exposure according to seasonal changes to maintain its health and vibrancy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tradescantia spathacea is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging new growth. Trim off any dead, damaged, or discolored leaves using sharp, clean scissors. To promote bushier growth, pinch back the tips of the stems regularly. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16985,"attracts":["Bees","Aphids"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Selenicereus grandiflorus, or the Queen of the Night cactus, prefers a moderate watering schedule. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out completely before watering again, as this cactus is prone to root rot if kept too moist. During the growing season (spring and summer), you may water more frequently, approximately every 7-10 days, depending on the humidity of your environment. Reduce watering significantly in the fall and winter months when the plant goes dormant, watering only enough to prevent the soil from fully drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This cactus thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, can scorch its delicate stems. Ideally, place the Selenicereus grandiflorus near a window where it can receive plenty of indirect light or in a location with dappled sunlight. If natural light is insufficient, you can supplement it with artificial grow lights. During the hottest summer months, you may provide some protection from extreme sun exposure, like a sheer curtain or a light shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Selenicereus grandiflorus is generally minimal but can help maintain its size and shape. Remove any dead or damaged stems as they appear, cutting back to a healthy part of the stem. Use a sharp, clean pair of scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts, which can reduce the risk of disease. If the plant becomes too large or unruly, you may also prune healthy stems to maintain the desired size, ideally doing so at the start of the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"queen of the night","description":"Selenicereus grandiflorus is a cactus species originating from the Antilles, Mexico and Central America. The species is commonly referred to as queen of the night, night-blooming cereus (though these two terms are also used for other species), large-flowered cactus, sweet-scented cactus or vanilla cactus. The true species is extremely rare in cultivation. Most of the plants under this name belong to other species or hybrids. It is often confused with the species of Epiphyllum.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America","Caribbean"],"other_name":["queen of the night"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Selenicereus grandiflorus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17196,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pseudevernia furfuracea, commonly known as tree moss or lichen, does not require traditional watering like other houseplants since it extracts moisture from the air. To ensure it maintains its health, an environment with adequate humidity is vital. Mist the lichen lightly with water every couple of weeks or if the air feels particularly dry, especially during winter when indoor heating can reduce humidity significantly. Avoid soaking it, as too much moisture can cause it to decay. Observing the lichen regularly can help in adjusting the misting frequency based on ambient conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pseudevernia furfuracea thrives best in indirect sunlight or shaded areas, resembling its natural habitat usually found on tree bark in forests. Place it in a spot with bright, filtered light to mimic these conditions, avoiding direct sunlight as it can dry out and damage the lichen. A north or east-facing window works well where the light is softer, providing a more indirect intensity. Limiting exposure to full sun helps prevent drying out and desiccation, allowing it to extract moisture from the atmosphere more effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pseudevernia furfuracea is not typically required as it is not a fast-growing or traditional plant but a type of lichen. If desired, trim any parts that appear brittle or excessively dull to encourage new growth and maintain the lichen's aesthetic appeal. Use sharp scissors and cut at the base of any discolored or damaged sections. Handling the lichen gently to avoid causing damage to its structure is essential. Besides occasional aesthetic trimming, regular pruning is unnecessary as the lichen will maintain its form naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tree moss","description":"Pseudevernia furfuracea, commonly known as tree moss, is a lichenized species of fungus that grows on the bark of firs and pines. The lichen is rather sensitive to air pollution, its presence usually indicating good air conditions in the growing place. The species has numerous human uses, including use in perfume, embalming and in medicine. Large amounts of tree moss is annually processed in France for the perfume industry.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["tree moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Pseudevernia furfuracea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16498,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Houstonia wrightii should be watered moderately. It thrives in well-drained soil and can tolerate some drought once established. During the growing season, ensure the soil remains slightly moist, but be careful not to overwater as it can lead to root rot. Allow the top layer of soil to dry out between watering to prevent over-saturation. In the winter, reduce the frequency of watering as the plant's growth slows down. Using a drip irrigation system or watering directly at the soil level helps minimize moisture on the foliage, which can reduce the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Houstonia wrightii prefers full sun to partial shade. It flourishes in bright, direct sunlight for most of the day but can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates or during peak summer months. For optimal growth and blooming, position the plant where it can receive at least 6 hours of sunlight daily. In regions with intense summer heat, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent scorching of the leaves. Ensure that the site has good air circulation to prevent the buildup of humidity, which can lead to mildew or fungal diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Houstonia wrightii involves minimal effort; typically, removing dead or damaged stems and foliage is sufficient. Prune in early spring before new growth starts to ensure the plant maintains a compact and tidy appearance. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms and extend the flowering period. If the plant becomes too leggy or sparse, consider cutting back some stems to stimulate bushier growth. Always use clean, sharp pruning scissors to minimize plant injury and reduce the risk of bacterial or fungal infections at the cut sites."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"pygmy bluet","description":"Houstonia wrightii (pygmy bluet) is a plant species in the Rubiaceae. Consistently check soil moisture to avoid underwatering or overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bocconia arborea thrives in full sun to partial shade. Indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive ample light, but consider some protection during the hottest parts of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bocconia arborea helps manage its size and shape, encouraging healthier growth. Lightly trim any overgrown or awkwardly shaped branches to maintain a balanced form. Sterilize your pruning tools before and after use to prevent the spread of disease. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16894,"attracts":["Birds","Squirrels"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus polymorpha, commonly known as the Monterrey oak or Mexican white oak, is a drought-tolerant tree that prefers a well-drained soil. After transplanting, it requires regular watering until established, typically for the first one or two growing seasons. Once established, it is very drought-resistant and should be watered deeply and infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided, especially in clay soils, as it can lead to root rot. During prolonged dry spells, some additional deep watering may be beneficial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus polymorpha thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the tree should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain healthy growth rates and a dense canopy. However, it can adapt to areas with some afternoon shade, particularly in hotter climates, to protect it from intense heat stress. Providing adequate sunlight helps the tree develop a strong structure and deep green foliage. If planting near structures or other trees, allow for ample space as this oak species can grow to be quite expansive both in height and width."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Quercus polymorpha, or Mexican white oak, should generally be done during the dormant season in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This tree requires minimal pruning, but dead, damaged, or diseased branches should be removed to maintain its health and appearance. Additionally, any crossing or inward-growing branches should be pruned out to encourage a strong, open structure. Be cautious not to remove more than one-third of the tree’s canopy at a time to prevent stress. Pruning mature oaks requires care to avoid pest and disease issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican White Oak","description":"Quercus polymorpha, the Mexican white oak, Monterrey oak or netleaf white oak, is a North American species of oak. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17389,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia prostrata, like many succulents, is drought-tolerant and does not require frequent watering. It's important to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During its active growing season in spring and summer, water sparingly, approximately every two to three weeks. In fall and winter, reduce the frequency even more, watering only once a month or when the plant shows signs of wilting. Overwatering is a common issue, so ensure that the pot has good drainage to prevent root rot. Always use room-temperature water and avoid wetting the leaves to prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia prostrata thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. A south or west-facing window is ideal if you are growing the plant indoors. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. If the plant begins to stretch or leaves lose their color, it may be an indication that it requires more sunlight. Conversely, too much direct sunlight might cause the leaves to bleach, so it's crucial to balance the exposure according to the plant's response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia prostrata is typically not necessary as the plant naturally maintains a low, spreading form. However, if desired, pruning can be done to control its growth or to remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems. The best time to prune is during the plant's dormant or early growing season, in late winter or early spring. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts. Always wear gloves when handling the plant, as the sap can cause irritation to the skin and eyes. Dispose of the pruned material properly to prevent any unwanted sap-induced contact or spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"prostrate sandmat","description":"Euphorbia prostrata is a species of spurge known by the common name prostrate spurge or prostrate sandmat.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["prostrate sandmat"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia prostrata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16794,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Petrea volubilis, commonly known as the Queen's Wreath or Sandpaper Vine, prefers consistent moisture but does not tolerate waterlogging. Water the plant deeply when the top inch of the soil dries out, ensuring that the water penetrates to the root zone. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, especially in dry, hot conditions. In the dormant season, reduce watering to allow the plant to rest. Always use well-draining soil to prevent root rot, and if the plant is in a container, ensure the pot has adequate drainage holes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Petrea volubilis thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce its best flowering display. It can tolerate partial shade, but too much shade will result in fewer blooms and weaker growth. Ideally, plant it in a sunny spot where it receives morning sunlight and some filtered afternoon sun in regions with intense heat. If you're growing it indoors, place it in a bright, south or west-facing window. Ensure that it is not exposed to cold drafts or extreme temperature fluctuations."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To maintain the health and appearance of Petrea volubilis, regular pruning is recommended. Prune lightly after the flowering season to remove spent flowers and any dead or damaged branches. This promotes bushier growth and more prolific flowering in the next cycle. In addition, you can perform a more substantial pruning in late winter to early spring to shape the plant and control its size. Be sure to use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent disease and damage to the plant. Always make cuts above a leaf node to encourage new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Queen's Wreath","description":"Petrea volubilis, commonly known as purple wreath, queen's wreath, sandpaper vine, and nilmani, is a species of plant in the vervain family, native to Central America. Gradually acclimate the plant to direct sunlight to prevent sunburn, particularly if it's been in low-light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula coccinea is relatively straightforward and mainly involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged leaves to maintain its shape and size. Morning sunlight with afternoon shade can be ideal, especially in hotter climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dichanthelium oligosanthes is generally minimal. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16202,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cladium mariscus, commonly known as fen-sedge, typically thrives in wetlands or areas with moisture-retentive soil. Regularly check the plant for any signs of disease or pests, removing affected parts immediately to prevent spreading."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Swamp Sawgrass","description":"Cladium mariscus is a species of flowering plant in the sedge family known by the common names swamp sawgrass, great fen-sedge, saw-sedge or sawtooth sedge. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17685,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Scilla peruviana prefers well-drained soil and should be watered regularly, especially during its growing season in the autumn and spring. However, it is crucial to avoid overwatering, as this can lead to bulb rot. The soil should be allowed to dry out slightly between waterings. In the summer, when the plant enters dormancy, reduce watering significantly. Ensure that the planting medium is not waterlogged and pots have sufficient drainage holes to prevent excess moisture accumulation. Monitor the plant's environment to adjust watering frequency depending on climate conditions, ensuring the soil remains just moist enough to sustain its bulbs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scilla peruviana thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive several hours of sunlight each day, particularly in the morning, to promote healthy growth and vibrant blooms. However, in regions with very intense sunlight, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. In cooler climates, more sunlight is typically better to support robust development. When planting, choose a location where the plant can bask in sufficient sunlight while also being protected from harsh midday rays. Adjust its position according to seasonal sun changes to optimize light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Scilla peruviana is quite straightforward. After the flowering period, it's essential to remove spent flowers to prevent the plant from putting energy into seed production, instead directing it towards strengthening the bulb for the following year. The foliage should be left to die back naturally, as the leaves are crucial for photosynthesis and for storing energy in the bulb. Once the leaves have withered and turned yellow, they can be trimmed back to ground level. Avoid cutting green, healthy leaves, as this may negatively impact the plant's future blooming potential."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Portuguese squill","description":"Scilla peruviana, the Portuguese squill, is a species of Scilla native to the western Mediterranean region in Iberia, Italy, and northwest Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean region","Portugal","Spain","Italy","North Africa"],"other_name":["Portuguese squill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Scilla peruviana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is essential to keep the soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot. During the spring and summer growing seasons, increase watering frequency, ensuring the plant receives adequate moisture without standing water. In fall and winter, reduce watering slightly as the plant's growth slows. Always use well-draining soil to facilitate proper water retention and drainage. Adjust your watering schedule based on humidity and temperature changes in your environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nicotiana plumbaginifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. When grown outdoors, it performs best when it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent scorching. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or east-facing window where it can get bright, indirect light. Insufficient light may lead to leggy growth with fewer flowers. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even light exposure and prevent the plant from leaning in one direction."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nicotiana plumbaginifolia is mostly about promoting bushy growth and removing any dead or diseased foliage. Regularly pinch back new growth at the tips to encourage a fuller plant shape. This can also stimulate more flower production. Remove spent flowers (deadheading) to prolong blooming and redirect the plant's energy into new growth. Cut back any yellowing or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's health. Prune towards the end of the growing season to prepare the plant for its dormant period, removing any excess growth that might not survive the winter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tex-Mex tobacco","description":"Nicotiana plumbaginifolia is a species of tobacco plant known as Tex-Mex tobacco. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16986,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Selenicereus spinulosus, commonly known as the fishbone cactus, requires careful watering. The plant thrives with infrequent yet thorough waterings. During the growing season (spring and summer), it is best to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. Reduce the water during the colder months of fall and winter when the plant's growth slows. Always use well-draining cactus soil and a pot with drainage holes to prevent excess moisture buildup. This cactus is drought-tolerant, so underwatering is preferable over overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Selenicereus spinulosus thrives in bright, indirect light. They prefer several hours of sunlight each day but should be protected from the harsh midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. Ideally, place the plant near an east-facing window where it can receive morning sunlight or a filtered light source. If grown outdoors, find a spot with partial shade. Although they can tolerate some direct sun, too much exposure may damage the plant. Regular rotation of the plant ensures even growth and prevents it from leaning towards the light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Selenicereus spinulosus is minimal and typically not necessary unless controlling size or removing dead or damaged stems. If pruning is needed, it is best done in the spring, just as new growth begins. Use sterile, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts near the stem's base or where you would like the plant to produce a new branch. Pruning can encourage branching and make the plant bushier. Handle with care as the plant has spines; wearing gloves is advisable to avoid injury."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"vine-like moonlight cactus","description":"Selenicereus spinulosus is a cactus species native to eastern Mexico and, possibly, the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas in the United States. Common names include vine-like moonlight cactus and spiny moon cereus. Its specific name, spinulosus, means \"with small spines\" in Latin.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["vine-like moonlight cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Selenicereus spinulosus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil is completely dry before watering again to avoid over-watering, which can lead to root rot. Adequate sunlight helps the plant develop its characteristic twisted and contorted foliage, while insufficient light may result in leggy growth and fewer flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Corokia buddleioides is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches using sharp, clean pruning shears. This plant can also be shaped into a hedge or a more compact form by trimming back the outer growth. Light pruning throughout the growing season can help maintain its desired shape. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Korokio","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Korokio"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Corokia buddleioides"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After blooming, as the plant enters dormancy, sunlight requirements become less critical."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Scilla luciliae is minimal and generally involves removing spent flowers to prevent unwanted self-seeding and to encourage the plant's energy to go back into the bulb for the next flowering season. When the flowers have faded, you can snip off the flower stalks. However, allow the foliage to die back naturally, as it is crucial for photosynthesis and storing nutrients back into the bulb. Do not cut the leaves while they are still green; they should be left until they turn yellow and wither away naturally."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Boissier's Glory-of-the-snow","description":"Chionodoxa luciliae (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16596,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lophophora williamsii, commonly known as peyote, prefers infrequent watering, reflecting its native arid environments. Water sparingly and allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growth period from spring to early autumn, watering can be moderate—approximately once every three to four weeks. In winter, reduce watering drastically or stop altogether to mimic natural dormancy conditions, preventing root rot. Always use a container with drainage holes and a well-draining cactus mix to ensure excess water doesn't accumulate, as the plant is highly susceptible to over-watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lophophora williamsii thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, mimicking the desert environment where it naturally occurs. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, particularly during morning or late afternoon, but harsh midday sun can scorch the plant. Ideally, this cactus should be placed near a south or east-facing window. If grown outdoors in suitable climates, provide it some shade during the hottest part of the day. For indoor cultivation, using grow lights during the winter months can help compensate for reduced natural light, encouraging healthy growth year-round."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lophophora williamsii is generally not necessary as it naturally maintains a compact shape. However, if there are damaged or diseased parts, these can be carefully removed with clean, sharp tools. Take care not to over-prune, as removing too much can stress the cactus. Removing pups or offsets can be done to control size or propagate new plants, but it's important to let any cut areas dry out completely before watering to prevent infection. Pruning can be done at any time, although the plant may respond best during its active growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Peyote","description":"Lophophora williamsii /loʊˈfɒfərə wɪlˈjæmsiaɪ/ or peyote (/pəˈjoʊti/) is a small, spineless cactus with psychoactive alkaloids, particularly mescaline. The English common name peyote is a Spanish loanword, which comes from the Nahuatl name peyōtl , said to be derived from a root meaning \"glisten\" or \"glistening\". Other sources translate the Nahuatl word as \"Divine Messenger\". {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16895,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus rugosa, commonly known as the netleaf oak, prefers moderate water once established. Initially, after planting, it should be watered deeply to help develop a strong root system. Once established, this oak tree can tolerate drought conditions, reflecting its adaptation to dry environments. However, during prolonged dry spells, you may offer occasional deep watering to mimic natural rainfall patterns, ensuring the water penetrates to the roots. Avoid overwatering to prevent root rot, and allow the soil to dry between waterings. Monitoring soil moisture levels can help tailor the watering schedule to local conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus rugosa thrives in full sun conditions, making it ideal for open areas where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. This oak species is adaptable to partial shade, but optimal growth and health are achieved under full sun exposure. Full sunlight is essential for the development of its dense foliage and robust structural growth. In locations with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can protect from leaf scorch. Selecting a planting site with adequate sunlight will also enhance the tree's resilience to pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus rugosa is best done during its dormancy in late winter or early spring. This timing minimizes the risk of disease transmission and allows for rapid healing. Pruning should focus on removing dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain tree health and structural integrity. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the tree; instead, perform light, corrective pruning to shape and encourage a strong framework for future growth. Remove any suckers or water sprouts that may sap energy from the main trunk, and ensure there is good air circulation through the canopy to prevent fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"netleaf oak","description":"Quercus rugosa, commonly known as the netleaf oak, is a broad-leaved tree in the beech and oak family Fagaceae. It is native to southern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["netleaf oak"],"pest_susceptibility":["Oak Twig Girdler","Leafminers"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Quercus rugosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent over-watering, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, water more frequently but make sure the soil has good drainage. Reduce watering in fall and winter when the plant is not actively growing. While it can tolerate partial shade, less sunlight can result in fewer blooms and leggy growth. Ensuring it gets plenty of sunlight will help maintain its vibrant yellow flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hunnemannia fumariifolia involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged foliage to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy appearance. Deadheading, or removing faded blooms, is beneficial as it promotes a longer flowering season. Cut back the plant in late fall as the growing season ends to about half its size to prepare it for new growth in the spring. Be cautious not to prune too aggressively as this could damage the plant. Regular light pruning can help to maintain its shape and encourage bushiness."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mexican tulip poppy","description":"Hunnemannia is a monotypic genus of flowering plants in the poppy family Papaveraceae, containing the single species Hunnemannia fumariifolia (tulip poppy or Mexican tulip poppy) native to the highlands of Mexico. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17792,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Catasetum integerrimum, like many orchids, requires a distinctive watering approach due to its growth pattern. During the growing season, typically spring to late summer, water the plant generously and frequently to keep the medium moist, but not waterlogged. As the plant enters its dormancy in the fall, gradually reduce watering. In the dormant period over the winter months, reduce watering further, allowing the potting medium to dry out between waterings. Resume regular watering as new growth appears in spring. Using rainwater or distilled water is preferred to avoid mineral build-up that can damage the plant roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Catasetum integerrimum thrives in bright, indirect light. During the growing season, it benefits from receiving plenty of light, ideally around 50% shade, similar to conditions found under a canopy in its native habitat. This means a position with morning sun or filtered light throughout the day is optimal. Avoid direct midday sun, which can scorch the leaves, especially if the plant is not acclimated to intense sunlight. During its dormancy period, reduced light is acceptable, as the plant has fewer energy requirements. Adjust the plant's exposure based on seasonal sunlight variations and growth phases to promote robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Catasetum integerrimum primarily involves cutting back flower spikes once they have finished blooming, as they won't rebloom and removing them helps conserve the plant's energy for new growth. If any leaves become yellow or diseased, remove them carefully to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of infection. Avoid trimming healthy roots as they are crucial for the plant’s nutrient absorption. After the plant enters dormancy and all leaves have naturally shriveled and fallen, you can clean up dead material from the pseudobulbs to maintain aesthetic appeal and ensure healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spurred Catasetum","description":"The Intact Catasetum (Catasetum integerrimum) is a species of orchid found from Mexico to Central America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Spurred Catasetum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Catasetum integerrimum"],"soil":["Loose","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16896,"attracts":["Birds","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus sinuata, commonly known as the bastard oak or Durand oak, generally requires minimal watering once established, as it is adapted to withstand drought conditions typical in its native habitats. However, newly planted or young Quercus sinuata trees benefit from regular watering to promote healthy establishment in the first growing season. Ideally, water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings to encourage deep root growth. Avoid waterlogging as this can lead to root rot or other diseases. As the tree matures, it should rely mostly on natural rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus sinuata thrives in areas with full sun exposure, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. It can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but its growth will be slower and less vigorous compared to when it receives more sunlight. When planting, ensure the site is well-drained and open enough to provide ample sunlight access throughout the day. Adequate sunlight is crucial for photosynthesis, promoting healthy foliage and robust growth, which contributes to the tree's overall strength and adaptability in various environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus sinuata is necessary to maintain a healthy and aesthetically pleasing form. The best time to prune is during the dormant season, late winter to early spring, before new growth begins. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16204,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clematis alpina requires consistent moisture to thrive, especially during its growing season in spring and early summer. Mulching around the base of the plant is beneficial for retaining soil moisture and maintaining a steady temperature. Be cautious not to over-water, as Clematis alpina does not like to sit in soggy soil, which can lead to root rot. In winter, reduce watering as the plant is dormant and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clematis alpina prefers a sunny position but can also tolerate part shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight a day to encourage optimal flowering, though it can tolerate afternoon shade. This balance helps protect the plant's roots from overheating while allowing the leaves and vines to soak up enough sunlight for healthy growth. Ensure that the base of the plant is shaded or mulched to keep the roots cool. In particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade is beneficial to prevent the foliage from scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis alpina is relatively straightforward. This species blooms on old wood, so pruning is best done immediately after the flowering period, usually in late spring or early summer. Remove any dead, damaged, or weak stems to promote healthy growth and enhance flowering for the next season. Be cautious not to prune too drastically unless necessary, as this can reduce the number of flowers. Light pruning helps maintain the plant’s shape and encourages a bushier growth. Remember that Clematis alpina generally needs only minimal pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alpine Clematis","description":"Clematis alpina or Alpine clematis is a flowering deciduous vine of the genus Clematis. Like many members of that genus, it is prized by gardeners for its showy flowers. It bears 1 to 3-inch spring flowers on long stalks in a wide variety of colors. C. alpina is native to Europe; in the United States it grows best in American Horticultural Society zones 9 to 6, which are generally found in the southern USA.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Alpine Clematis"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Clematis alpina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16988,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senecio pseudoarnica, commonly known as sea beach ragwort, requires moderate watering. It’s vital to let the soil partially dry out between waterings, as this plant prefers well-draining conditions to avoid waterlogged roots. Water thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch, ensuring excess water drains away. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s better to err on the side of dryness. During the plant's active growing season in spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, while in winter, watering should be reduced."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio pseudoarnica thrives in bright, indirect sunlight to partial sun. This plant is well-suited to locations where it receives plenty of light but is protected from the intense midday sun, which can scorch its leaves. Ideally, place it in a spot that gets several hours of morning sunlight with dappled shade or bright filtered light during the afternoon. While it can adapt to lower light conditions, its growth may slow down. If grown indoors, placing it near a window with sheer curtains can help mimic its preferred lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio pseudoarnica is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. You should remove any dead, damaged, or yellowing leaves regularly. Light pruning can be done throughout the growing season by pinching back leggy or unruly stems to promote bushier growth. If the plant becomes too large or leggy, more substantial pruning can be done in early spring before new growth begins. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears and make cuts just above a leaf node or joint to support continued healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Seabeach Groundsel","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["USA","Russia"],"other_name":["Seabeach Groundsel"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Senecio pseudoarnica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17594,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Globularia cordifolia, commonly known as heart-leaved globe daisy, prefers well-drained soil and does not tolerate overwatering. Water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During the active growing season in spring and summer, regular watering is necessary, but ensure the soil is not soggy. In the dormant winter months, reduce watering to prevent root rot. Overwatering is a common issue, so it's crucial to adapt your watering schedule based on the plant's environment and the soil's moisture level. Achieving the right water balance is key for a healthy plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Globularia cordifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, provide it with at least 6 hours of sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some light shade, too much shade may result in fewer blooms and leggy growth. In very sunny regions, a bit of afternoon shade can help protect the plant during the hottest part of the day. Be sure to consider the plant's natural environment; a location that mimics a sunny alpine or rocky hillside is ideal for supporting its growth and flowering potential. Adjust the position if necessary to match its light preferences."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Globularia cordifolia is generally minimal, as this plant maintains a compact growth habit. However, light pruning can help promote more vigorous growth and flowering. Prune back any dead or damaged stems in early spring before the growing season begins. Once the flowers have bloomed and begun to fade, you can deadhead the spent flowers to encourage further blooming. Be careful not to cut too much of the foliage as it’s crucial for photosynthesis. Overall, simple maintenance pruning will help keep your heart-leaved globe daisy looking tidy and healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Matted Globularia","description":"Globularia cordifolia (heart-leaved globe daisy) is a species of flowering plant in the family Planataginaceae, native to the mountains of central and southern Europe, and western Turkey.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Matted Globularia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Globularia cordifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17497,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lamprocapnos spectabilis, commonly known as bleeding heart, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry periods, ensuring the soil remains evenly moist. However, avoid overhead watering to prevent foliage diseases. It is crucial to reduce watering in the late summer as the plant goes dormant. Make sure the plant is not left in standing water, as this can lead to root rot. Ensuring sharp drainage can help maintain the right moisture balance for these delicate perennials."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The bleeding heart plant thrives best in partial to full shade. It prefers dappled sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade, which mimics its natural woodland habitat. Direct, harsh sunlight, especially in hot climates, can scorch the leaves and cause wilting. If grown in a sunnier location, ensure the soil remains moist and consider providing some shade during peak sun hours. Striking the right balance of light will ensure healthy growth and an abundance of the plant's characteristic heart-shaped blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For pruning Lamprocapnos spectabilis, begin by removing dead flowers to prevent seed formation and encourage more blooms. Once flowering is finished and the foliage starts yellowing, cut back the plant near ground level to tidy the appearance and allow energy storage in the roots. Ensure your tools are clean and sharp to prevent disease transmission. Prune carefully in early spring if needed, but avoid excessive trimming as this can impact summer blooms. Routine maintenance promotes a robust and thriving bleeding heart."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Asian Bleeding-heart","description":"Lamprocapnos spectabilis (bleeding heart or Asian bleeding-heart) is a species of flowering plant in the poppy family Papaveraceae, native to Siberia, northern China, Korea and Japan. It is the sole species in the monotypic genus Lamprocapnos, but is still widely referenced under its old name Dicentra spectabilis (now listed as a synonym). It is valued in gardens and in floristry for its heart-shaped pink and white flowers, borne in spring.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Korea"],"other_name":["Asian Bleeding-heart"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slug"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Lamprocapnos spectabilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, it's best to water it moderately, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering should be avoided as the roots might rot. In the winter, reduce watering frequency significantly to prevent moisture accumulation, especially since this plant is dormant during colder months. Overall, it's vital to ensure well-drained soil to mimic its native environment and keep it healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nolina microcarpa thrives in full sun and prefers bright, direct light for an optimal growth environment. However, it is also tolerant of partial shade, especially in very hot climates where some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorching. It's important to avoid placing it in low-light conditions, as this can lead to leggy growth and reduced vigor. Providing sufficient sunlight will help maintain its natural compact shape and encourage healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nolina microcarpa is generally minimal, as it's a low-maintenance plant. Regular pruning can include removing dead or damaged leaves, especially at the base, to maintain its appearance and prevent potential pest infestations. If the plant becomes overcrowded or misshapen, selective pruning can help to maintain its form, but heavy pruning is rarely necessary. Always make sure to remove any pruned material away from the plant to avoid attracting pests."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sacahuista","description":"Nolina microcarpa is a species of flowering plant in the asparagus family known by the common names sacahuista and palmilla. It does occur in the southwestern corner of Utah, where it has a limited distribution on Navajo Sandstone, but reports of it occurring in Texas may be in error.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["sacahuista"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Nolina microcarpa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Direct sunlight can scorch their leaves, so it's best to keep them away from windows with harsh sunlight. Always monitor the plant's response when adjusting its lighting conditions to prevent any stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spathiphyllum wallisii is typically minimal but helps maintain its appearance and health. Remove any yellowing, brown, or wilted leaves by cutting them at the base where they meet the stem. This can encourage better growth and prevent the plant from expending energy on unhealthy foliage. Dead or faded flowers should also be removed to promote new blooms. Consider wearing gloves, as the plant's sap can be mildly irritating. The plant’s natural habitat is nutrient-rich waters, so periodic monitoring of the water quality can also be beneficial for its health. During dry seasons, if grown in ornamental ponds, ensure that evaporation does not significantly lower water levels, as this could stress the plant. Ensure that all pruned parts are removed from the water to avoid unwanted propagation and maintain ecological balance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Water caltrop","description":"The water caltrop is any of three extant species of the genus Trapa: Trapa natans, Trapa bicornis and the endangered Trapa rossica. It does not require frequent watering. During dry spells, you can mist it lightly to maintain humidity, but avoid overwatering as this may lead to root rot. In a natural setting, it is adapted to absorb moisture from the surrounding air and rainfall, so allowing it to dry out slightly between waterings can mimic its natural environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Racomitrium lanuginosum thrives in partial to full sunlight but can also tolerate some shade. Ideally, provide it with bright, filtered light to mimic its natural alpine or subarctic habitats. If growing it indoors, place it near a window where it can receive indirect sunlight for most of the day. Direct sunlight for extended periods may cause scorching, while too little light can hinder its growth and make it leggy. Adjust its location according to seasonal sunlight variations."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Racomitrium lanuginosum is rarely necessary as it maintains a low, mat-like growth habit. However, if you wish to keep it tidy or control its spread, you can trim back excess growth using clean scissors. Remove any dead or discolored portions to encourage healthy growth and avoid fungal problems. Regular pruning isn't needed unless for aesthetic reasons or managing its size in a specific setting like a garden landscape or terrarium."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Woolly Fringe-moss","description":"Racomitrium lanuginosum is a widespread species of moss found in montane and arctic tundra across the Northern and Southern hemispheres. It grows as large mats on exposed rock and in boulder scree, particularly on acidic rocks. Its leaves have a characteristically decurrent and toothed hair-point, which gives rise to its regional common names woolly fringemoss, hoary rock-moss and woolly moss.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green, Grey"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Woolly Fringe-moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Racomitrium lanuginosum"],"soil":["Acidic","Gravelly","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering frequency during the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. This plant is sensitive to tap water with high mineral content, so it's best to use distilled or rainwater. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, and avoid letting the plant sit in excess water in the saucer. Ensure the plant is rotated periodically for even growth and to prevent it from leaning toward the light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Calathea zebrina mainly involves removing dead or damaged leaves to encourage new growth and maintain an attractive appearance. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut leaves at the base of the stem. Regularly check for any signs of pests or diseases, and remove affected leaves promptly. It's also beneficial to occasionally trim any leggy growth to keep the plant compact. Pruning can be done at any time of the year as needed, but more extensive pruning is best performed in the spring or early summer during the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Zebra-plant","description":"Calathea zebrina, the zebra plant, is a species of plant in the family Marantaceae, native to southeastern Brazil.
