{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16797,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phacelia dubia prefers well-draining soil that remains consistently moist, especially during its active growing season in spring and early summer. It is recommended to water this plant moderately, ensuring the soil does not become waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. However, avoid letting the soil completely dry out between waterings. During the hotter months, increase the frequency of watering to prevent the plant from experiencing drought stress. In cooler seasons, reduce watering and allow the top inch of the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to mimic its natural dormancy cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, Phacelia dubia should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure optimal growth and blooming. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent wilting and scorching of its foliage. If grown in partial shade, ensure that the plant still receives adequate light, as too much shade can result in weak, leggy growth and reduced flowering. Adjust the plant's location as necessary to provide the best balance of sunlight exposure for vigorous growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phacelia dubia is not intensive, as it generally only requires minimal maintenance. Remove any dead or damaged stems and leaves to promote healthy growth and to maintain a tidy appearance. Deadheading, or cutting back spent flowers, can encourage further blooming and extend the flowering period. This practice also helps prevent self-seeding if you do not wish the plant to spread excessively. It's best to perform any pruning or trimming during the growing season, being careful not to cut back too severely, as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Appalachian phacelia","description":"Phacelia dubia (known by the common names smallflower phacelia or Appalachian phacelia) is an annual forb native to the eastern United States, that produces cream colored or light blue flowers in early spring.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Appalachian phacelia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Phacelia dubia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16300,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dichondra argentea, commonly known as Silver Falls, requires regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's crucial to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings, especially to avoid root rot in this low-lying plant. In summer, more frequent watering may be necessary, while in winter, it should be reduced. Ensure the plant has good drainage, whether in the ground or in containers, to prevent water accumulation. Consider using a well-draining potting mix if grown in a container."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dichondra argentea thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, the plant prefers at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily to achieve best growth and its characteristic silver appearance. However, it can tolerate light shade, but this might result in a more subdued foliage color and less vigorous growth. In hotter climates, a bit of afternoon shade can help prevent sunburn or excessive drying out. It's adaptable and can be grown indoors, but this usually requires strong indirect light or supplemental grow lights to mimic outdoor conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dichondra argentea is relatively simple and infrequent. It benefits from occasional trimming to maintain its shape and encourage dense growth. You can prune lightly to control its spread or remove any leggy, damaged, or dead vines to keep the plant tidy. Typically, pruning is best done in spring or early summer. With a pair of sterilized scissors, snip back the stems where necessary. Regular trims encourage bushier growth and can prevent the plant from becoming too spindly or overgrown, especially if it's used as a ground cover."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"silver ponysfoot","description":"Dichondra argentea, the silver ponysfoot or silver nickel vine, is a species of flowering plant in the family Convolvulaceae. It is disjunctly distributed in New Mexico, Texas, Mexico, Colombia, Bolivia, northwest Argentina, and southeast Brazil, and has gone extinct in Arizona. A creeping perennial reaching 4 in (10 cm) high but growing 4 to 6 ft (1 to 2 m) long, and hardy in USDA zones 10 through 12, in cultivation it is grown as annual, chiefly as a hanging...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Silvery-gray"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern USA"],"other_name":["silver ponysfoot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Dichondra argentea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17200,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hypholoma brunneum, commonly known as the \"brick cap,\" is a type of mushroom that prefers moist environments. In a cultivation setting, ensure the substrate or growing medium remains consistently moist but not waterlogged to mimic its natural habitat. Over-watering can lead to issues such as the growth of mold or undesirable bacteria. It's best to water gently and allow for proper drainage. Maintaining a humid environment can help support its growth, so consider using a humidity tent or regular misting if necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypholoma brunneum requires indirect light as it naturally grows in shaded environments like under forest canopies or in areas with dappled sunlight. Direct sunlight can dry out the growth medium and elevate temperatures to unsuitable levels. If growing indoors, placing the mushroom in an area with natural filtered light or under artificial lights at low intensity is ideal. Controlling the light exposure will help maintain the required humidity levels and prevent the substrate from drying out, which is crucial for successful growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not commonly applicable to Hypholoma brunneum as it is a fungus and not a vascular plant. Instead of pruning, focus on proper harvesting techniques. When harvesting, gently twist and pull the mature mushrooms from the substrate, being careful not to disturb the surrounding mycelial network. This method helps ensure continued growth and reduces the risk of damage that could hinder future fruiting bodies from developing. Dispose of any decaying or parasitic mushrooms to maintain optimal growing conditions."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"chocolate button woodtuft","description":"Hypholoma brunneum is a species of mushroom in the family Strophariaceae. It was originally described in 1899 by George Edward Massee as Flammula brunnea. Derek Reid transferred it to the genus Hypholoma in 1954.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["chocolate button woodtuft"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Hypholoma brunneum"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17794,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cyrtopodium macrobulbon requires moderate watering to thrive. It is important to keep the potting medium slightly moist at all times, without allowing it to become waterlogged. Water the plant thoroughly once the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch, avoiding any excess that may lead to root rot. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, watering should be more frequent to support active growth. In fall and winter, when the plant enters dormancy, reduce watering significantly, allowing the medium to dry out more between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyrtopodium macrobulbon thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct morning sun but should be protected from the harsh afternoon sunlight, which can scorch its leaves. Ideally, place it in a location where it receives filtered sunlight for several hours a day. If the plant is grown indoors, a position near an east-facing window is favorable. Ensure the plant does not sit under direct, intense sun rays for prolonged periods, as this may lead to leaf burn. Adjust light conditions seasonally to suit its growth or dormancy phase."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cyrtopodium macrobulbon involves removing dead or diseased foliage and flower spikes. After the flowering period, which occurs mainly in spring, cut back flower spikes once they have browned and dried out. This helps conserve the plant's energy for growth next season. Remove any yellowing leaves or those affected by pests or diseases to improve air circulation and overall plant health. Always use sterilized shears or scissors to prevent infections. Minimal pruning during the dormant period is advised, as excessive trimming can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cyrtopodium macrobulbon"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16702,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nolina texana, commonly known as Texas beargrass, is drought-tolerant and prefers infrequent watering. It is best to allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it's crucial to err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering. During the growing season in spring and summer, you can water more frequently, perhaps every two to three weeks, while in the dormant winter months, reduce watering to once a month or even less if conditions are particularly dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nolina texana thrives in full sun conditions but can also tolerate partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. If kept in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and not flower as prolifically. It's a hardy plant that can withstand intense sunlight and high temperatures, making it perfect for xeriscaping in hot, dry climates. However, if moved indoors or to a heavily shaded area, make the transition gradually to prevent shock, and ensure that it still receives adequate bright light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nolina texana is generally minimal. Remove dead or damaged leaves at the base to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage new growth. Pruning is best done in the spring before the plant enters its active growth phase. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease. Be cautious not to remove too much foliage at once, as this can stress the plant. Regular cleaning and removal of old leaves will help the plant thrive and look its best, but extensive pruning is not typically necessary for this hardy plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas Sacahuiste","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Texas Sacahuiste"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Nolina texana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is best to prune this plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to improve air circulation and prevent disease. Regular pruning encourages compact growth and a more bushy appearance, enhancing its ornamental appeal."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Lindheimer's Senna","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Texas","Mexico"],"other_name":["Lindheimer's Senna"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Senna lindheimeriana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17099,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Triantha glutinosa prefers moist to wet conditions, reflecting its native habitat in bogs and marshes. When growing this plant, ensure the soil is consistently damp, but not waterlogged, to mimic these conditions. Water it frequently, especially during warmer seasons, keeping an eye on the surface moisture of the soil. During cooler months, the frequency can be reduced but ensure that the soil never dries out completely. Using distilled or rainwater can be beneficial, as it reduces the risk of mineral buildup that can stress the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Triantha glutinosa thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to flourish and produce its distinctive flowers. However, in hotter climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat stress. If grown indoors, placing it near a bright window with southern or eastern exposure will provide the necessary sunlight. Ensuring it receives the right amount of light will support healthy growth and vibrant blooms throughout its growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Triantha glutinosa is generally minimal because it is a herbaceous perennial that dies back at the end of the growing season. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to encourage healthy new growth. After the flowering period, you can trim back the flower stalks to the base to maintain the plant's appearance and prevent unwanted self-seeding. It's best to perform any necessary pruning during the plant's dormant stage in late fall or early winter to prepare it for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sticky False Asphodel","description":"Triantha glutinosa, commonly known as the sticky false asphodel, sticky tofieldia or northern bog asphodel, is a species of flowering plant in the tofieldia family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Canada","United States"],"other_name":["Sticky False Asphodel"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Triantha glutinosa"],"soil":["Moist","Peat"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17688,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Taphrina deformans, known commonly as peach leaf curl, is not a plant, but a fungus affecting peach and nectarine trees. Managing water is important by providing consistent moisture without waterlogging the soil. Ensure good drainage and avoid wetting foliage during watering, as excess moisture can promote fungal diseases. Focus on early morning watering to allow leaves to dry throughout the day, reducing the chance of infection. Adjust watering according to seasonal changes to maintain soil moisture without creating a damp environment conducive to the growth of the fungus."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Peach trees, the hosts for Taphrina deformans, require full sun to grow healthily and minimize disease impacts. Sunlight is essential as it aids in the drying of foliage and openings from pruning cuts, reducing favorable conditions for the disease. Plant the trees in a location where they receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. Adequate sunlight, combined with good air circulation, helps to keep the foliage dry and less susceptible to fungal infections such as leaf curl. Monitoring and adjusting shading may also be required based on tree location and seasonal sun changes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential in managing Taphrina deformans. During dormancy, prune and destroy all infected twigs and branches to reduce overwintering fungal spores. Removing any heavily infected shoots helps to prevent the spread of the disease. Prune for better air circulation and sunlight penetration, reducing humidity around leaves that favors fungal growth. Focus on the center of the tree to open it up, which diminishes disease incidence by allowing quicker drying and better air movement. Always use sterilized pruning tools to avoid further spreading the fungus."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Peach Leaf Curl","description":"Taphrina deformans is a fungus and plant pathogen, and a causal agent of peach leaf curl.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Peach Leaf Curl"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Taphrina deformans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17988,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polystichum setiferum, commonly known as the soft shield fern, prefers consistently moist soil. It should be watered regularly to keep the soil damp but not waterlogged. Allow the top layer of the soil to dry out slightly between waterings, but ensure it doesn't dry out completely. During the growing season, typically spring through early fall, these ferns may require more frequent watering, while in winter, the frequency can be reduced. Avoid watering the foliage directly to prevent leaf spot and ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polystichum setiferum thrives in partial to full shade environments, making it ideal for shaded gardens or woodland settings. It can tolerate some morning sun, but direct afternoon sun, especially during the hotter months, can scorch the fronds. If grown indoors, the soft shield fern should be placed in a location with indirect light. Avoid placing it in areas with strong, direct sunlight, or in very dark areas, to ensure its fronds remain lush and vibrant. Providing dappled light mimics its natural woodland habitat and supports healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polystichum setiferum involves removing dead or damaged fronds to promote healthy growth and maintain its attractive appearance. This can be done periodically throughout the growing season or during late winter to early spring before new growth appears. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut back the spent fronds close to the base. Be cautious not to damage the crown of the plant, as this can affect new growth. Regular pruning will also help improve air circulation around the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"soft shield fern","description":"Polystichum setiferum, the soft shield-fern, is an evergreen or semi-evergreen fern native to southern and western Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Macaronesia"],"other_name":["soft shield fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails","Fungal diseases"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Polystichum setiferum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Humus-rich","Moist","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Additionally, after the plant has finished blooming, remove spent flower stalks to encourage new growth and prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil","Central America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Neomarica gracilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

To ensure optimal growth, choose a planting location that receives ample sunlight while still providing some relief during peak sunlight hours if needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ranunculus fascicularis is not typically necessary as it is a low-maintenance plant. This involves pinching or cutting off the flower stems a few inches above the base once the blooms have faded. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged foliage as needed to promote air circulation and reduce the risk of disease. During the dormant period in late summer, cut back any remaining foliage as it dies back naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Early Buttercup","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Early Buttercup"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ranunculus fascicularis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18078,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cheilanthes sieberi, commonly known as mulga fern, requires careful watering to thrive. It prefers a dry environment and does not need excessive watering. Ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings to mimic its natural rocky habitats. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's better to underwater than to water too frequently. It is typically sufficient to water these ferns every two to three weeks, depending on the humidity and temperature of your environment. Use a well-draining soil mix to prevent water from accumulating around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cheilanthes sieberi thrives in partial to full shade conditions. It is adapted to grow under the canopy of taller plants or in rocky crevices with filtered sunlight, typical of its natural habitat. Too much direct sunlight can burn the fronds and cause browning, while too little can stunt growth. Ideally, place the plant in an area where it receives morning sun and afternoon shade, or indirect sunlight throughout the day. Adjust the lighting based on how the plant responds; its fronds should remain a healthy green if the light conditions are suitable."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cheilanthes sieberi involves removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage healthy growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut fronds at the base. Prune in late winter or early spring before the new growth starts, which is the ideal time to assess the plant’s health and aesthetics. Regularly check for any discolored or dead parts and prune as necessary. Infrequent light pruning can also help manage the plant's size and shape, especially if it is growing too large for its space."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"cloak fern","description":"Cheilanthes sieberi is a small fern growing in many parts of Australia, New Zealand and nearby islands. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17291,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Brachycereus nesioticus, a cactus native to the Galápagos Islands, thrives in arid conditions and requires very little water. This plant has adapted to survive with minimal moisture, typical of its natural habitat, and is extremely drought-resistant. During its growing season, from spring to early fall, water it sparingly, ensuring the soil is dry between waterings. In the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly, sometimes not watering at all. Be cautious of overwatering, as this can lead to root rot and other health issues for the cactus."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brachycereus nesioticus prefers bright, direct sunlight, mirroring the conditions of its native Galápagos environment. It thrives under full sun exposure, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight a day to grow and flourish. In indoor settings, position the cactus near a south-facing window where it can receive ample light. If full sun exposure is not possible, use artificial grow lights to supplement its light needs. Be cautious of sudden changes in light intensity, as this could cause stress or sunburn. Gradually acclimate the plant if introducing to brighter conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is rarely necessary for Brachycereus nesioticus, as it grows slowly and maintains a tidy form on its own. However, should you encounter any damaged or diseased parts of the plant, it is beneficial to prune them promptly to maintain the cactus's health. Use sterile, sharp tools to avoid introducing pathogens. Remove any discolored or shriveled segments carefully, cutting back to healthy tissue if needed. Regularly inspect the plant to catch any potential issues early, but overall, this cactus requires little to no regular pruning."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Lava Cactus","description":"The lava cactus is a species of cactus, Brachycereus nesioticus, the sole species of the genus Brachycereus. The plant is a colonizer of lava fields – hence its common name – where it forms spiny clumps up to 60 cm (24 in) tall. Its solitary white or yellowish white flowers open in the daytime. It is endemic to the Galápagos Islands.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Gal��pagos Islands"],"other_name":["Lava Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Brachycereus nesioticus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17595,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Casimiroa edulis, commonly known as white sapote, prefers well-drained soil and regular watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. During hot or dry spells, you may need to water more frequently. Reduce the frequency of watering during the winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure there is proper drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Casimiroa edulis thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. For optimal growth and fruit production, it's best to provide the plant with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorching and stress. If you're growing the tree indoors or in a greenhouse, make sure it receives ample light by placing it near a south-facing window or providing supplemental grow lights. Ensure young trees are gradually acclimated to full sun to avoid sunburn on the leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Casimiroa edulis is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy fruit production. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Begin by removing any dead, broken, or diseased branches. Then, thin out any crossing or crowded branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. After blooming, the parent plant will gradually start to produce offsets or \"pups.\" These pups can be left attached to form a clump or removed and replanted when they are about one-third the size of the parent plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Medusa's head","description":"Tillandsia caput-medusae is a species of flowering plant in the bromeliad family, Bromeliaceae, subfamily Tillandsioideae. The thick, channeled, tapering and twisting leaves are up to 25 cm (9.8 in) long and are covered in fine gray hairs. The rosette of leaves arise from an inflated pseudobulb. Pups are produced after blooming, as is usual...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central America","Mexico"],"other_name":["Medusa's head"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Offset Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Tillandsia caput-medusae"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In general, watering once every two to three weeks should suffice, but this may vary depending on the humidity and temperature of its environment. During the growing season, you can slightly increase the frequency of watering, but always be cautious not to overwater."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Notholaena standleyi prefers bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate periods of direct sun, especially in the cooler parts of the day. It naturally grows in rocky, sunlit areas, so aim for a location in your home that mimics these conditions, like a south or west-facing windowsill with filtered light. Avoid prolonged exposure to harsh afternoon sunlight, which can scorch its delicate fronds. If you notice browning or wilting, consider relocating the plant to a spot with less direct light. In winter, when light levels are lower, ensure the plant receives as much indirect sunlight as possible."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Notholaena standleyi is generally minimal since this fern does not require frequent trimming. However, it is beneficial to remove any dead or damaged fronds to maintain its appearance and overall health. Gently trim these at their base using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. This process helps to prevent the spread of disease and encourages new growth. However, avoid over-pruning as this can stress the plant. Regularly checking your fern for any unsightly fronds and trimming them when necessary will help keep your Star Cloak Fern looking its best."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"star cloak fern","description":"Notholaena standleyi, also known as star cloak fern and Standley's cloak fern, is a fern that is native to the United States and Mexico. It is distinguished by the pentagonal shape formed by the blades of its frond, a property other members of the Notholaena genus do not possess.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["star cloak fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Notholaena standleyi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The best time to prune is in the spring. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts at the base of unwanted stems. Always wear gloves to protect your hands from the plant's spines. If the plant becomes too large or unruly, selective pruning of the stems can help maintain an appropriate size and shape without harming the plant's health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Andes organ pipe cactus","description":"Cereus hildmannianus is a species of cactus from southern South America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16899,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ranunculus glacialis, commonly known as the glacier buttercup, is adapted to alpine conditions where water is often abundant from melting snow. However, in cultivation, maintaining a consistent moisture level without waterlogging is key. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist, replicating its natural wet environment, especially during its growing season. Ensure excellent drainage to prevent root rot. During dormancy or if kept indoors for winter, reduce watering to prevent over-watering, imitating the drier conditions it would experience when covered in snow during winter."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ranunculus glacialis thrives in full sunlight to mimic its high-altitude, alpine environment. It needs plenty of light to bloom profusely, ideally around 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. In more temperate regions, ensure the plant is placed in a spot where it can receive ample morning sunlight and some afternoon shade to protect it from intense heat. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window, but ensure it does not overheat. Providing adequate sunlight helps maintain its growth and flower production cycles."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ranunculus glacialis should focus on removing any dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and appearance. During its active growing season, trim back any spent flowers to encourage further blooming and prevent seed formation, which can sap energy. Avoid aggressive pruning unless the plant is exceedingly large or tangled. Once the growing season ends, allow the plant to naturally die back, cleaning up any debris to prevent disease. In its natural habitat, this plant is accustomed to harsh conditions, so minimal intervention is often best."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Glacier Crowfoot","description":"Ranunculus glacialis, the glacier buttercup or glacier crowfoot, is a plant of the family Ranunculaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Alps","Pyrenees"],"other_name":["Glacier Crowfoot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ranunculus glacialis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16990,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senna occidentalis, commonly known as Coffee Senna, requires moderate watering to thrive. It prefers consistently moist soil but is tolerant to short periods of drought. During the growing season, ensure the soil remains evenly moist, but take care not to overwater and cause waterlogged soil, as this can lead to root rot. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant’s growth slows. Ideally, water it when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Always ensure that the plant has proper drainage to prevent water retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senna occidentalis thrives in full sun conditions. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. The plant can tolerate partial shade, particularly in hot climates, but its growth and flowering may be less vigorous. In environments where sunlight is scarce, ensure the plant receives the maximum possible amount of light. Insufficient sunlight may lead to weak stems and fewer blooms. When growing indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window or use artificial grow lights if necessary to match its light requirements."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senna occidentalis helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. Ideally, prune the plant in the early spring before the new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first. Trimming back overgrown branches will help promote bushier growth and better air circulation. Make clean cuts close to the main stem or just above a leaf node using sharp pruning shears. Regular pruning can prevent the plant from becoming too leggy and encourages more prolific flowering. If any pods are not wanted, remove them to prevent the plant from self-seeding."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coffee Senna","description":"Senna occidentalis is a pantropical plant species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Tropical America","Caribbean"],"other_name":["Coffee Senna"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Senna occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Pruning not only helps to keep the plant tidy and vigorous but also improves air circulation, reducing the risk of pest and disease issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bear's foot","description":"Smallanthus uvedalia, known as hairy leafcup, bear's foot, and yellow flower leafcup, is a herbaceous perennial native to the Central and Eastern United States. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17292,"attracts":["Insects","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Plagianthus divaricatus, commonly known as the saltmarsh ribbonwood, requires moderate watering. However, it is also quite adaptable and can tolerate dryer conditions once established. During the growing season, water it regularly, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. In winter, reduce the frequency of watering, as the plant requires less moisture during its dormant period. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogged conditions, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Plagianthus divaricatus thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It is well-suited to environments with direct sunlight but can also tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates. For optimal growth, ensure the plant receives at least 6 hours of sunlight per day, which promotes healthy foliage and vigorous flowering. If planted in a partially shaded area, ensure it still gets a significant amount of light throughout the day to prevent leggy growth. When choosing a location for planting, consider its natural coastal habitat, which is typically open and sunny."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Plagianthus divaricatus is generally minimal. Regular pruning is not necessary but can be done to manage size or shape and to remove any dead or damaged branches. It is best to prune after the flowering period to avoid cutting off the developing blooms for the next year. Simply trim back to a healthy lateral branch or to the main stem, ensuring cuts are clean to prevent disease. Pruning helps maintain the plant's health and encourages bushier growth, especially if some older branches are removed to allow light and air into the center of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Makaka","description":"Plagianthus divaricatus or saltmarsh ribbonwood is a plant that is endemic to New Zealand. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17100,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tribulus cistoides, commonly known as puncture vine, thrives in dry, arid conditions and is very drought-tolerant. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it is essential to let the soil dry out between waterings. Ensure the plant is not sitting in water, as it prefers to remain relatively dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tribulus cistoides prefers full sunlight and thrives best when exposed to direct sunlight for at least six to eight hours a day. Ensure that it receives substantial sunlight to maintain its compact growth and vibrant blooms, as it naturally grows in sun-drenched environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tribulus cistoides is generally not necessary but can be done to control its spread or shape the plant. It's best to prune in the late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to snip back any overgrown or wayward stems. Removing spent flowers can encourage a tidier appearance and prevent seed formation if the plant is becoming invasive. Keep in mind that this plant can spread aggressively if left unchecked, so periodic pruning helps manage its size and shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Jamaican feverplant","description":"Tribulus cistoides, the Jamaican feverplant or puncture vine, is a species of flowering plant in the Zygophyllaceae family, which is widely distributed in tropical and subtropical regions.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","South America"],"other_name":["Jamaican feverplant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Tribulus cistoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When watering, allow the soil to dry out partially before re-watering to prevent waterlogging, which it does not tolerate well. During the growing season, especially in hotter climates, increase watering frequency to ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not soggy. Reduce watering in the cooler months to mimic natural drying cycles."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acrocomia aculeata thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. This robust palm species is typically found in open areas that receive ample sunshine. When planted in somewhat shaded conditions, the growth may slow down, and the plant may not develop its characteristic lush foliage. To ensure healthy development, choose a planting location that will guarantee maximum sunlight exposure. In hot climates, ensure the plant is well-watered, particularly when exposed to intense midday sun, to prevent heat stress and dehydration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Acrocomia aculeata should focus on removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain plant health and aesthetics. Use clean, sharp tools to cut the fronds close to the trunk, avoiding damage to surrounding healthy foliage. Prune minimally, as excessive cutting can stress the plant. Removing older fronds also helps reduce pest habitats. The best time to prune is during the plant's dormant period, usually in late fall or winter, to minimize stress and any potential shock. Avoid pruning green, healthy fronds as they are vital for the plant's photosynthesis and overall health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Macaw palm","description":"Acrocomia aculeata is a species of palm native to tropical regions of the Americas, from southern Mexico and the Caribbean south to Paraguay and northern Argentina. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18108,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dillenia indica, commonly known as the elephant apple tree, prefers moist conditions and should be watered regularly. However, it is important to avoid waterlogging, as too much standing water can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to ensure the roots receive adequate oxygen. During the growing season, especially in warmer climates or summer months, you may need to increase watering frequency to keep the soil consistently moist, but always make sure the soil has good drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dillenia indica thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, provide it with at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with intensely hot and sunny climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. However, in less intense climates, full sun is preferable as it promotes denser foliage and more abundant fruit production. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Dillenia indica should be done primarily to maintain its shape and to remove dead or damaged branches. Pruning is best done during the dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any crossing branches to improve air circulation within the canopy, which helps prevent disease. When pruning, always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and avoid tearing the bark. Light trimming can also help if you wish to keep the tree at a manageable size, particularly when grown in gardens or smaller spaces."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"elephant apple","description":"Dillenia indica, commonly known as elephant apple or chulta, is a species of Dillenia native to southeastern Asia, from India, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka east to southwestern China (Yunnan) and Vietnam, and south through Thailand to Malaysia and Indonesia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Greenish yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Indian Subcontinent","Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["elephant apple"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Dillenia indica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17293,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pelecyphora aselliformis, commonly known as the \"Turbinicarpus\", requires careful watering to prevent root rot. Water the plant sparingly during the growing season (spring and summer) by allowing the soil to completely dry out between waterings, as overwatering is a common cause of failure in cultivation. During the dormant season (fall and winter), reduce the watering frequency significantly. Ensure good drainage and use a cactus mix to facilitate excess water escape. It's crucial to adjust watering practices based on environmental factors like humidity and temperature to keep the plant healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pelecyphora aselliformis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It requires at least 4 to 6 hours of light daily for ideal growth. Direct sunlight can be too harsh, especially during the hottest part of the day, and can cause sunburn, leading to unsightly blemishes on the cactus. When growing indoors, place the cactus near a south-facing window where it can receive ample indirect light while avoiding direct afternoon rays. If grown outdoors, provide some light shade, such as under a taller plant or mesh cover, to filter the sunlight and protect it from intense sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pelecyphora aselliformis is generally minimal, as this cactus grows slowly and retains its shape well. Occasionally, older plants may develop unsightly dead growth or pups that you may wish to remove to maintain the plant’s aesthetic appearance. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to carefully remove any dead or damaged spines and spent flowering parts at their base. Always handle the plant with care to avoid accidentally damaging the small cactus or its delicate spines. Pruning is best done during its active growing seasons, spring and summer, to promote quick recovery."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":null,"description":"Pelecyphora aselliformis is a species of Pelecyphora found in Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Pelecyphora aselliformis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17396,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phellinus robiniae, commonly known as the locust tree heart rot fungus, does not require watering as it is a fungus that typically grows on black locust trees (Robinia pseudoacacia). As a wood-decaying fungi, its growth depends on the moisture content of the host tree's wood rather than external watering. Ensuring that the environment surrounding the host plant is not overly dry can potentially aid the fungus's natural growth processes, but active watering is not necessary or beneficial for its development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phellinus robiniae itself does not require sunlight as it is a fungus and not a photosynthetic organism. Its presence and impact relate more to the health and condition of the host tree rather than external light conditions. However, maintaining the host tree in optimal health, including proper sunlight exposure, can potentially help in managing the overall stress level of the tree, even though direct light has no effect on the growth of the fungus."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Phellinus robiniae as it is a fungal organism rather than a plant with traditional flowers or leaves. For the health of trees that host it, however, any removal of visibly infected or decaying wood might be attempted by cutting away affected areas. However, this may not eradicate the fungus as it deeply colonizes the heartwood. Consulting a professional arborist for advice on managing the impacts on host trees may be necessary."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Cracked Cap Polypore","description":"Phellinus robiniae, commonly called the cracked cap polypore, is a fungus of the family of Hymenochaetaceae. The fungus primarily infests black locusts, aided by openings caused by Megacyllene robiniae infestation, but also grows on various other trees such as Carya, oak, and Acacia. Cracked cap polypore is sympatric with most of its hosts. It has a brown spore print, leaving brown streaks on the tree below the fungus.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Cracked Cap Polypore"],"pest_susceptibility":["Heart rot"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Phellinus robiniae"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17597,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cnidoscolus multilobus, commonly known as the bull nettle, prefers well-drained soil and moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant, so it’s important to let the soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Water deeply but infrequently, ensuring that excess water drains well and the soil remains relatively dry. During its active growing period in spring and summer, increase the watering frequency slightly, but always check soil moisture levels before watering again. Reduce watering significantly in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cnidoscolus multilobus thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure healthy growth. The plant can tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but too much shade will result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. If grown indoors or in low-light areas, consider supplementing with grow lights to provide adequate light. Ensure the plant is not shadowed by taller surrounding plants, as inadequate sunlight could lead to poor growth and decreased vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cnidoscolus multilobus is not often necessary, but can be beneficial in maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. The best time to prune is during its dormant period in late winter or early spring. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches, cutting them back to healthy tissue. For aesthetic pruning or shaping, trim the plant to the desired size, ensuring to use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread. Regular pruning also helps to encourage new growth and healthier foliage. Be cautious as the plant's sap can be irritating to the skin."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cnidoscolus multilobus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17500,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Medicago falcata, commonly known as yellow alfalfa, is a drought-tolerant perennial plant that requires moderate watering. It's crucial not to overwater this plant, as it thrives in well-drained, somewhat dry soils. Water the plant deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between each watering session. During the rainy season or in areas with high humidity, you might need to adjust the frequency to prevent soggy conditions that could lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Medicago falcata prefers full sun exposure to thrive and produce the best blooms and foliage. It requires a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight daily, making it ideal for open fields or sunny garden spots. In regions with intensely hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to reduce stress on the plant. However, too much shade can lead to reduced flowering and a less robust plant, so finding the right balance is essential for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Medicago falcata is generally minimal and mostly involves removing dead or damaged growth to encourage new, healthy shoots. Late winter or early spring is the best time to perform pruning, as this prepares the plant for the growing season. If left unchecked, the plant may become leggy, so light trimming can help maintain its shape and promote denser growth. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers can extend the bloom period and improve overall plant vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sickle alfalfa","description":"Medicago falcata is a plant species of the genus Medicago. It is native to the Mediterranean basin, but is found throughout the world. It forms a symbiotic relationship with the bacterium Sinorhizobium meliloti, which is capable of nitrogen fixation. Its common names include yellow lucerne, sickle alfalfa, yellow-flowered alfalfa, yellow alfalfa, sickle medick and yellow medick.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["sickle alfalfa"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Medicago falcata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17202,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cladonia fimbriata, commonly known as trumpet lichen, typically thrives in climates with high humidity. In cultivation, it does not require frequent watering. Instead, it should mimic natural conditions, where it absorbs moisture from the air and occasional rainfall. Ensure the plant is not overwatered, as it prefers to dry out between waterings. Mist the plant lightly with water once a week or so to maintain humidity levels, especially if it's kept indoors. Avoid direct water contact on the lichens; light misting is sufficient for keeping them hydrated and healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cladonia fimbriata prefers indirect sunlight, mimicking its natural habitat on forest floors and shaded areas. It thrives in dappled light conditions where it receives plenty of ambient light without being exposed to the harsh midday sun. Direct sunlight can cause the lichen to dry out and potentially damage it. If kept indoors, place the plant near a window with filtered light or where it will receive gentle morning or late afternoon sun. Maintaining a balance of light is crucial for its growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Cladonia fimbriata does not require regular pruning. However, you can trim away parts of the lichen that appear damaged or are no longer viable. Pruning is mainly an aesthetic choice, as dead or dying sections can be removed to improve appearance. Use small, sharp scissors to carefully snip away unwanted sections without disturbing the remaining plant. It's best to minimize disturbance to the plant, as it can be sensitive to handling. Ensure that you do not cut too much as this could affect its growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Trumpet Lichen","description":"Cladonia fimbriata is a species of lichen belonging to the family Cladoniaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Northern Hemisphere"],"other_name":["Trumpet Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Fragmentation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cladonia fimbriata"],"soil":["Rocky","Gravelly","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In the cooler months, reduce watering even further, maintaining just enough moisture to keep the plant alive. Always avoid over-watering and water-logged conditions by ensuring the plant has good drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cheilanthes austrotenuifolia thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16399,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Evolvulus nuttallianus, commonly known as shaggy dwarf morning-glory or Nuttall's evolvulus, prefers well-drained soil with minimal moisture. It is drought-tolerant, making it ideal for xeriscaping. Water the plant thoroughly but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s crucial to ensure proper drainage. During winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy. In hotter climates, you may need to water a bit more frequently, but always prioritize letting the soil dry out fully to prevent any fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Evolvulus nuttallianus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant is native to open sunny areas, so it performs best when exposed to plenty of light. In regions with extremely hot summers, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch. When planted in the right location with ample sunlight, it will produce more vibrant flowers and maintain a healthy growth habit. Lack of sufficient light can result in sparse blooming and leggy growth, reducing its overall appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Evolvulus nuttallianus is relatively minimal. To maintain a tidy appearance and encourage bushier growth, occasional trimming is beneficial, especially after flowering. Remove any dead or damaged stems at any point during the growing season. Trimming spent flowers can also encourage more blooms and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of diseases. It is not necessary to prune aggressively as the plant naturally maintains a compact form."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Shaggy dwarf morning-glory","description":"Evolvulus nuttallianus is a species of flowering plant in the morning-glory family known by the common name shaggy dwarf morning-glory. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16600,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Watering Lumnitzera racemosa, commonly known as the white-flowered black mangrove, requires attention to its natural habitat preferences. This plant thrives in coastal and mangrove regions, often in saline or brackish water conditions. For optimal growth, ensure that its soil is consistently moist, especially during its growing season. It may require additional watering during dry spells. However, avoid overwatering to prevent root rot, especially if grown in less saline conditions. If planted in pots, ensure that drainage is adequate to keep roots healthy. Regular watering mimicking tidal movements can be beneficial in mimicking its natural habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lumnitzera racemosa, a species adept at surviving harsh coastal conditions, flourishes in full to partial sunlight. Ideally suited for regions with high light availability, it is important to place this plant where it can receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily. If cultivated further inland or in urban settings with limited direct light, ensure it receives partial sun throughout the day to mimic its native environment. While adaptable to fluctuating light conditions, consistent exposure to sunlight supports robust growth and enhances its flowering potential. Providing adequate light is crucial for maintaining its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lumnitzera racemosa should focus on maintaining a healthy structure and encouraging bushy growth. Prune during the dormant period, ideally in late winter or early spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood to promote airflow and reduce disease risk. Trim back any overly long branches to balance the tree's structure and encourage new growth. Regular pruning helps manage the plant's size, especially in managed landscapes or smaller gardens. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16800,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phellodendron amurense, commonly called Amur cork tree, prefers a moderately moist but well-drained soil. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established, though regular watering is beneficial during the early stages of its growth. Ensure the soil does not completely dry out, particularly in hot, arid conditions. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot; thus, allow the soil to become slightly dry between waterings. A good practice is to water deeply but less frequently, allowing the roots to grow deeper into the soil in search of moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This tree does best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth, though it can tolerate partial shade conditions as well. Full sun exposure encourages a healthy, expansive growth habit and a dense canopy. When planting in areas with intense afternoon sunlight, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching. In areas with milder sunlight, full sun is ideal. Ensure it's planted in a location where it receives ample light to thrive effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phellodendron amurense should be done primarily to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any crossed or overcrowded branches to allow sunlight and air to penetrate the canopy, promoting healthy growth. Being a large tree, ensure any structural pruning maintains the plant's natural form and structure. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the tree; instead, focus on minor adjustments yearly to guide its development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Amur Corktree","description":"Phellodendron amurense is a species of tree in the family Rutaceae, commonly called the Amur cork tree. It is a major source of huáng bò (Chinese: 黄柏 or 黄檗), one of the 50 fundamental herbs used in traditional Chinese medicine. The Ainu people used this plant, called shikerebe-ni, as a painkiller.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["East Asia"],"other_name":["Amur Corktree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Phellodendron amurense"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17690,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Iris × hollandica requires moderate watering. It's crucial to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during the active growing season in spring. Water regularly, but ensure that the soil does not become waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. Reduce watering once the foliage begins to die back in summer. During dormant periods, particularly in winter, the plant requires very minimal watering. A good rule of thumb is to water when the top inch of soil feels dry. Always water at the base of the plant to avoid wetting the foliage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris × hollandica thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, this flower should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure robust flowering. While it can tolerate some partial shade, too little light can result in fewer blooms and weaker growth. If planted in a shadier area, ensure it's still receiving a few hours of sunlight, preferably during morning hours. Ensuring good light exposure also helps in maintaining shorter and stronger stems, making the plant more resistant to wind damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Iris × hollandica should focus on removing spent flowers and dead leaves. Once the blooms have faded, cut the stalks down to the base to prevent seed production and encourage stronger growth. After the bloom, allow the foliage to naturally die back, as this process helps the plant store energy for the next growing season. Only remove leaves once they are yellow or brown and have completely wilted. Regularly clearing away dead and diseased foliage helps prevent fungal issues and pest infestations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dutch iris","description":"Iris × hollandica, commonly known as the Dutch iris, is a hybrid iris developed from species native to Portugal,Spain and North Africa (Iris tingitana × Iris xiphium).","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Spain","Portugal"],"other_name":["Dutch iris"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Rust","Gray mold"],"propagation":["Bulbs","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Iris × hollandica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16504,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hydrocotyle bonariensis, commonly known as pennywort or penny grass, prefers consistently moist soil. It thrives in environments where the soil is kept uniformly damp but not waterlogged. Ensure that the plant is watered regularly, particularly during dry spells, to prevent the soil from drying out completely. However, be cautious to avoid water stagnation, which can lead to root rot. Ideally, water the plant early in the morning to allow any excess moisture on the leaves to evaporate during the day, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hydrocotyle bonariensis thrives in a range of light conditions, but it prefers partial to full sun exposure. In hot climates, it benefits from light shade during the peak sun hours to prevent leaf scorch. In temperate regions, more sunlight can enhance its growth. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright window where it can receive filtered light. Adequate sunlight ensures robust and healthy foliage, but it's essential to monitor the plant for signs of sun stress, which can manifest as browning or wilting leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hydrocotyle bonariensis is not always necessary, but it can help maintain its shape and encourage healthier growth. Trim back overgrown stems and any dead or diseased foliage using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. Regular trimming can prevent the plant from becoming too leggy and invasive, particularly in garden settings where it is used as ground cover. It's best to prune during the growing season, in spring or summer, to promote new growth and ensure the plant remains lush and vigorous."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"largeleaf pennywort","description":"Hydrocotyle bonariensis, the largeleaf pennywort, once a member of the family Apiaceae, now in the family Araliaceae and of the genus Hydrocotyle is a hairless and creeping perennial.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States","Mexico","South America"],"other_name":["largeleaf pennywort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hydrocotyle bonariensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, water moderately, especially if rainfall is insufficient. However, in cooler months, reduce watering frequency. Monitor local weather conditions to adjust watering schedules accordingly. It is best to water this plant early in the morning or late in the afternoon, allowing the foliage to dry throughout the day, which helps minimize the risk of fungal infections."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leucospermum cordifolium thrives in full sunlight. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to produce abundant blooms and maintain vigorous growth. Ideally, plant it in a location where it will receive consistent sun exposure throughout the day. In regions with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching, but generally, more sunlight leads to healthier plants. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, place the plant near a sunny window or under grow lights to simulate natural sunlight conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Leucospermum cordifolium should be done to encourage bushy growth and promote blooming. It is best to prune after flowering, which typically occurs in spring. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems promptly to maintain plant health. Cut back approximately one-third of the growth to stimulate new growth and flower production. Avoid cutting into the older wood, as this may hinder the plant's ability to produce flowers in the next season. Regular pruning helps maintain a compact shape and prevents the plant from becoming too leggy or overgrown."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"The Pincushion","description":"Leucospermum cordifolium is a shrub assigned to the Proteaceae native to South Africa. It flowers between the middle of July and the end of November.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["The Pincushion"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Leucospermum cordifolium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, it prefers being watered every 7 to 10 days when the soil feels dry. It's important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, as it does not thrive in consistently moist or soggy conditions. In winter, reduce watering significantly, only watering once the soil is completely dry. Proper drainage is crucial, so using a well-draining soil mix is recommended to support its preference for dry to semi-arid conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senna roemeriana thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to flourish and produce an abundance of blooms. Its preference for bright conditions makes it well-suited for sunny borders, rock gardens, or containers placed in well-lit outdoor areas. Inadequate sunlight exposure may lead to reduced flowering and leggy growth. It can tolerate partial shade, especially in hot climates, but optimal blooming is achieved in consistent, direct sunlight. Ensure it receives ample light by avoiding planting in areas where it might be overshadowed by taller plants or structures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Senna roemeriana generally requires minimal pruning to remain healthy and attractive. Pruning should primarily be conducted in early spring, just before the start of the growing season. Remove any dead or damaged branches to improve airflow and overall plant health. Lightly trim back leggy stems to encourage a fuller habit. Avoid excessive pruning, which can stress the plant. If necessary, perform additional light maintenance pruning throughout the growing season to maintain desired shape and size, as well as to remove any spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Two-leaved Senna","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Two-leaved Senna"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Senna roemeriana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Consider using sheer curtains to diffuse the light or artificial grow lights if natural sunlight is insufficient, especially during short winter days."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Oncidium sphacelatum primarily involves removing spent flower spikes and dead or damaged pseudobulbs. Pruning should also include occasional trimming of dead leaves or old sheaths, which helps improve air circulation and overall plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Kandyan Dancer Orchid","description":"Oncidium sphacelatum is a species of orchid ranging from Mexico to Central America, southeastern Venezuela. You can also trim back the plant to maintain its shape and size, but avoid cutting into older wood, as this can inhibit regrowth. After flowering, deadheading the spent blooms can promote bushier growth and potentially a longer flowering season. It's important to ensure good air circulation to prevent excessive dampness and potential fungal issues. If growing indoors, ensure it is placed in an area with bright, indirect light. Additionally, it's important to replicate its natural habitats, which include shaded areas in forests, to ensure optimal health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Hypogymnia imshaugii in the same way as for vascular plants. This process should be done gently to avoid damaging the delicate structure of the lichen. Monitoring its health and ensuring that it has ample space to spread is important, as lichens naturally expand over suitable substrates without intervention."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Imshaug's Tube Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Imshaug's Tube Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Hypogymnia imshaugii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During dry spells or extremely hot weather, a deep soak every two to three weeks should suffice. It's important to note that overwatering can harm the plant more than underwatering. When young, it might require slightly more frequent watering until well-established. Once mature, it can survive on natural rainfall in most environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eysenhardtia texana thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight a day to perform well. Ensuring it receives ample sunlight will enhance its ability to thrive in its native habitat conditions and exhibit optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Eysenhardtia texana is typically minimal but can be necessary to maintain shape and remove any damaged or dead branches. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on cutting back any crossing, dead, or diseased branches first. Light shaping can be done to encourage a more compact form, but avoid excessive pruning which may reduce flowering. Regular trimming of suckers at the base is advisable to prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce plant stress."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas Kidneywood","description":"Eysenhardtia texana, commonly known as Texas kidneywood, bee-brush, or vara dulce, is a species of small flowering tree in the legume family, Fabaceae. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before the plant enters its main growing period. Additionally, deadheading spent flowers can also encourage further blooming and overall plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"marmalade-bush","description":"Streptosolen is a genus of flowering plants with a single species, Streptosolen jamesonii, the marmalade bush.
