{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17897,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tillandsia multicaulis, like all air plants, absorbs water through its leaves, as it does not have traditional roots. Mist the plant thoroughly a couple of times a week, ensuring that it receives enough water to stay hydrated. During warmer months or in dry environments, increase the frequency to 3-4 times a week. Alternatively, you can soak the plant in water for about 20-30 minutes every week. After watering, the plant should be allowed to dry completely in about 4 hours to prevent rot. Adjust watering routine based on humidity and temperature conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tillandsia multicaulis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, making it ideal for placement near a window where it can receive filtered light. Direct sunlight, especially during peak midday hours, may be too intense and can scorch the leaves. However, some morning or late afternoon sun can be beneficial. If kept indoors, a spot with plenty of light, such as near a south or east-facing window, is preferred. In lower light situations, the plant may survive but growth will be slower, and it may not bloom as frequently. Adjust its location based on the intensity of light it needs and the season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tillandsia multicaulis involves removing dead or brown leaves to encourage healthy growth and maintain aesthetics. Gently pull away any loose, dead leaves by hand or use sterilized scissors to trim them at the base. Pruning is typically not needed often, as air plants are slow-growing. If the plant produces offsets, or pups, these can be removed to propagate new plants once they've reached about one-third to one-half the size of the parent plant. Regularly inspect the plant for any signs of disease or decay, pruning them promptly to maintain health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"swamp fire","description":"Tillandsia multicaulis is a species in the genus Tillandsia. This species is native to Central America and Mexico (from Chiapas north to Hidalgo).","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["swamp fire"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Offset Propagation","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Tillandsia multicaulis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade may be beneficial, though generally, they are quite tolerant of strong sun from morning until late afternoon."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lupinus havardii is generally minimal but can enhance the plant's health and appearance. Dead heading, or removing spent blooms, encourages further blooming and prevents the plant from going to seed too early. Prune away any dead or diseased foliage promptly to maintain plant health. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid infection or damage to the plant tissues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Big Bend Bluebonnet","description":"Lupinus havardii is a species of lupine known by the common names Big Bend bluebonnet and Chisos bluebonnet. Regular pruning helps to promote more blooms in the upcoming growing season and maintain the desired shape and size of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"queen of Philippines","description":"Mussaenda philippica (Filipino: agboy) is a plant species in the family Rubiaceae that grows as a shrub or small tree. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17398,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pittosporum eugenioides, also known as lemonwood, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered regularly but not excessively. During the growing season, keep the soil consistently moist but allow the top layer to dry between waterings. Reduce watering in the winter months as the plant requires less moisture. Always check the soil moisture level before watering to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Ensure good drainage in both pots and garden beds to maintain the health of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. However, it can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates, which can help protect it from intense afternoon sun. When planted in partial shade, the growth may be slower, and the plant may not be as bushy. Ensuring the plant has adequate sunlight will promote lush, healthy foliage and a strong, vigorous plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pittosporum eugenioides should be done mainly in late winter or early spring before new growth begins, to maintain its shape and encourage dense foliage. Trim back any dead or damaged branches and thin out overcrowded areas to improve air circulation. You can also lightly prune throughout the growing season to maintain a desired shape and size. Avoid heavy pruning, which can shock the plant, and always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tarata","description":"Pittosporum eugenioides, common names lemonwood or tarata, is a species of New Zealand native tree. Growing to 12 m (39 ft) tall by 5 m (16 ft) broad, it is conical when young but more rounded in shape when mature. Its adaptability to sunny, dry conditions makes it ideal for xeriscaping and landscapes in arid or semi-arid regions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Tridens albescens is generally minimal, as it is a low-maintenance grass species. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17992,"attracts":["Birds","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Protea compacta, commonly known as the 'compact protea', prefers well-draining soil and requires moderate watering. It is crucial to avoid over-watering, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply once every 1 to 2 weeks, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During hot and dry periods, increase the frequency slightly, but always ensure good drainage. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture without causing waterlogging. Reduce watering in the cooler months when the plant is not actively growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Protea compacta thrives in full sun and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow and flower successfully. It is best suited for an outdoor location that receives ample sunlight. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to provide sufficient light. Lack of sunlight can result in poor flowering and leggy growth. In colder climates, ensure the plant is protected from frost as it can damage the foliage and flowers. In extremely hot climates, partial shade during peak midday heat can prevent sunburn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Protea compacta is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging vigorous flowering. The best time to prune is after the flowering season ends. Use sharp, clean secateurs to remove dead or damaged stems, and trim back flowering stems just below the old flower head. Avoid cutting into the older wood, as proteas do not regenerate well from mature wood. Regularly removing spent flowers and dead branches will help promote new growth and a more compact shape. Light pruning can also help aerate the plant and prevent pest infestations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bot River Sugarbush","description":"Protea compacta is similar to Protea eximia. Its distribution is from the Kleinmond to Bredasdorp Mountains and is one of the best known proteas in the cut flower industry. Its leaves curve upward.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Bot River Sugarbush"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Protea compacta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to handle with care, as lichens can be fragile. Pruning might encourage a more aesthetically pleasing appearance or help in renewing the growth in cultivated environments."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Poplar Sunburst Lichen","description":"Gallowayella hasseana, the poplar sunburst lichen, is a species of corticolous (bark-dwelling), crustose lichen in the family Teloschistaceae. You can either mist it lightly or soak the plant in water for an hour, and then let it drain completely. Adjust frequency based on the environment's humidity and temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Selaginella lepidophylla thrives in indirect or low-light conditions. If placed outdoors, choose a shady spot where it gets dappled sunlight. The plant can handle a range of light conditions but prefers those mimicking its natural desert floor habitat with indirect sunlight and consistently warm temperatures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Selaginella lepidophylla is generally minimal. Since it grows slowly and doesn't typically develop unruly growth, the primary reason for pruning is to remove any dead or discolored fronds. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to snip off these parts at their base to prevent disease and maintain the plant's aesthetic. Pruning can also help encourage new growth, though it's not always necessary. Inspect the plant regularly and remove any debris or dead foliage to ensure good air circulation around the plant and to promote a healthy growing environment."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"resurrection plant","description":"Selaginella lepidophylla (syn. Aim to water the plant approximately once a week during dry spells. For mature trees, ensure they're watered once every 2-3 weeks during extreme drought conditions, adapting to the prevailing weather and soil conditions. Always allow the soil to dry out between watering to prevent root rot, ensuring a healthy and robust growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus laceyi thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and development. While it can tolerate partial shade, too little sunlight may result in slower growth and reduced foliage density. This oak is well-suited for hot climates, as it can withstand intense sunlight once established. When planting, choose a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day, enhancing its growth and vitality. Providing the right amount of sunlight will ensure a healthy, vibrant tree."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus laceyi is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree's health. Light pruning can improve structural integrity and air circulation. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the tree. Focus on removing crossed branches or those that disrupt the natural shape of the tree. Use clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts that the tree can easily heal. Regular light pruning helps maintain a desirable shape and encourages healthier, more uniform growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lacey Oak","description":"Quercus laceyi, the Lacey oak, is a small to medium-size deciduous oak tree which is native to northeastern Mexico (Coahuila and Nuevo León) and to the Texas Hill Country in central Texas in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Lacey Oak"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus laceyi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16497,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Houstonia serpyllifolia, commonly known as Thymeleaf Bluet, prefers consistently moist soil, especially during its active growing season in spring and early summer. It thrives in naturalistic settings like woodland gardens or rocky slopes where it can benefit from regular rainfall. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. This helps to prevent root rot, a condition to which many Houstonia species can be prone if kept too wet. Take care not to water directly on the leaves to reduce the risk of fungal disease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thymeleaf Bluet thrives best in locations with partial to full sun exposure. It enjoys morning sun and can tolerate some light shade, especially in hotter climates, to prevent the foliage from wilting. A site that provides about 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day is ideal. In areas with intense afternoon sun, providing some dappled shade can help maintain its vibrant foliage and beautiful blooms. If grown in too much shade, the blooming can be reduced, and the plant may become leggy, striving for more light. Adjust its location accordingly to optimize its growth conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Houstonia serpyllifolia is generally minimal as it is a small, low-growing perennial. Pinch back spent flowers to encourage more blooms and to maintain a tidier appearance. At the end of the flowering season, you can trim back any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth in the following season. Regularly inspect the plant for signs of disease or insect damage and remove affected parts as necessary. This light maintenance encourages vigorous growth and a healthier plant overall, while also controlling the shape and size for aesthetic purposes in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Thyme-leaved Bluet","description":"Houstonia serpyllifolia, (common names creeping bluet, mountain bluet, thymeleaf bluet, Appalachian bluet) is a plant species in the Rubiaceae. It is native to the eastern United States, primarily the Appalachian Mountains. The name \"serpyllifolia\" alludes to the resemblance between this plant and the culinary herb wild thyme, Thymus serpyllum. Houstonia serpyllifolia grows in Pennsylvania, Maryland, West Virginia, western Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee, and northeastern Georgia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Thyme-leaved Bluet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Houstonia serpyllifolia"],"soil":["Acidic","Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17788,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Echeveria bifida is a succulent plant that requires careful watering because of its sensitivity to overwatering. Water the plant when the topsoil is completely dry, typically every 1-2 weeks depending on your climate and the season. Ensure the pot has a drainage hole to prevent water from pooling at the bottom, as stagnant water can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering frequency significantly as the plant's growth slows and its water needs decrease."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echeveria bifida thrives best with plenty of sunlight, preferring bright, indirect light. It's ideal to place the plant near a window that gets several hours of morning sun but is shielded from intense afternoon rays, which can scorch the leaves. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with a grow light. During hotter months, you may need to move the plant slightly back from the window to prevent leaf burn. Consistent, adequate light supports healthy coloration and compact growth in this succulent."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Echeveria bifida, pruning is minimal but can be beneficial for maintaining the plant’s health and appearance. Remove dead or dying leaves at the base as they occur by gently pulling them away. This not only improves appearance but also prevents pests and disease. If the plant becomes too tall or leggy, you can trim the stem and propagate the cuttings. Be careful not to damage the main rosette while pruning, as this is the central and most vital part of the plant's structure."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Aphids","Root rot"],"propagation":["Leaf Cutting","Offsets"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Echeveria bifida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17285,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Decatropis bicolor, a shrub or small tree native to arid and semi-arid regions, requires minimal watering, making it ideal for xeriscaping. During its growing season, ensure the soil is thoroughly drenched, then allow it to dry out completely before the next watering session. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other fungal diseases. Reduce watering frequency significantly during the dormant season, generally winter. Test soil moisture levels frequently, especially in container-grown specimens, to prevent overwatering. This species has adapted well to infrequent water supply and performs best when under-watered rather than over-watered."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Decatropis bicolor thrives in conditions where it can receive full sun exposure. This plant is well adapted to warm climates and can tolerate direct sunlight for most of the day. Ensure that it receives at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight daily to promote robust growth and flowering. In regions with intense heat, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. However, too much shade can lead to poor growth and sparse foliage. When grown indoors or in partially shaded areas, monitor its sunlight exposure to ensure it mimics its natural habitat as closely as possible."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Decatropis bicolor should be done sparingly and primarily focused on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Late winter or early spring is the ideal time for any significant trimming, allowing the plant to concentrate its energy on new growth during its active season. This species can be shaped to maintain desired dimensions or to remove crossed branches that might cause friction damage. However, heavy pruning should be avoided as it can stress the plant. Regular inspections for any branch die-back or pest infestations can determine the necessity for additional, minor pruning tasks."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Decatropis bicolor"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17591,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agave attenuata is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant thoroughly once the soil has dried out completely, which typically means every 1-2 weeks depending on climate conditions. In the fall and winter, reduce watering frequency to once a month or less. It's important to ensure the plant is never sitting in waterlogged soil to prevent root rot. Use pots with drainage holes or plant directly in well-draining soil if growing outdoors."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agave attenuata thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers bright, indirect sunlight if indoors, and full sun outdoors in cooler climates. In regions with intense heat or full sun exposure for prolonged periods, some afternoon shade may benefit the plant to prevent sunburn. When introducing the plant to more light, do so gradually to prevent shock. A position with morning sun and afternoon shade can often provide the ideal lighting conditions. Keeping the sunlight consistent helps maintain the plant's growth and color without stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Agave attenuata is not usually necessary, but it can be done to maintain its shape and remove dead leaves. Dead or damaged leaves should be removed at their base, taking care not to damage the healthy tissue. If the plant produces offsets or pups around its base, these can be removed if desired, either to propagate new plants or to maintain the parent plant's appearance. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp tools to prevent infection. Regular inspection will help keep the plant healthy and looking its best."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Swan-neck Agave","description":"Agave attenuata is a species of agave sometimes known as the \"lion's tail,\" \"swan's neck,\" or \"foxtail\" for its development of a curved stem, unusual among agaves. Native to the plateau of the State of Jalisco in central Mexico, as one of the unarmed agaves, it is popular as an ornamental plant in gardens in many other places. It is reportedly naturalized in Madeira and Libya.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Swan-neck Agave"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Offsets"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Agave attenuata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16793,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Petiveria alliacea prefers well-drained soil and moderate watering. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, it is advisable to water the plant once or twice a week, depending largely on the environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. It's important to let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In the cooler months, reduce the watering frequency, allowing the plant to experience a slightly drier period. Always check the soil before watering to ensure it hasn't retained excess moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Petiveria alliacea thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, position the plant where it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. However, it can tolerate some afternoon shade, especially in warmer climates to prevent leaf scorching. When grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. If natural light is insufficient, fluorescent lights can supplement to ensure the plant receives adequate light for healthy growth. Always monitor the plant for signs of light deficiency or excess, adjusting its position as needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Petiveria alliacea is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It's best to prune the plant in the early spring before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to prevent the spread of pathogens. Ideally, place the Selenicereus grandiflorus near a window where it can receive plenty of indirect light or in a location with dappled sunlight. If natural light is insufficient, you can supplement it with artificial grow lights. During the hottest summer months, you may provide some protection from extreme sun exposure, like a sheer curtain or a light shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Selenicereus grandiflorus is generally minimal but can help maintain its size and shape. Remove any dead or damaged stems as they appear, cutting back to a healthy part of the stem. Use a sharp, clean pair of scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts, which can reduce the risk of disease. If the plant becomes too large or unruly, you may also prune healthy stems to maintain the desired size, ideally doing so at the start of the growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"queen of the night","description":"Selenicereus grandiflorus is a cactus species originating from the Antilles, Mexico and Central America. The true species is extremely rare in cultivation. Most of the plants under this name belong to other species or hybrids. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the plant is never sitting in standing water. During prolonged dry periods, especially in sandy soils, a little more water is beneficial, but natural drought resilience makes this a low-maintenance plant in terms of irrigation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus myrtifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. When planted in areas with less sun, growth may become leggy and less robust. Providing ample sunlight ensures the plant maintains a full, lush canopy with healthy foliage and overall vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus myrtifolia should be done selectively, primarily to remove dead or damaged branches or to improve the tree's shape and strength. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth starts, which helps to minimize stress on the plant. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts. Avoid heavy pruning, as this oak species naturally maintains a well-rounded form. Regularly checking for and removing diseased or insect-infested branches can also promote healthier growth. Regular inspection and minimal intervention are key due to its naturally compact and manageable growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Myrtle Oak","description":"Quercus myrtifolia, the myrtle oak, is a North American species of oaks in the beech family. It's essential to water the plant deeply, ensuring that the soil is moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering in the fall and winter as the plant enters dormancy. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, and always use well-draining soil to maintain adequate moisture levels without over-saturating the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris domestica thrives in full sun and requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day to flourish. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure ensures robust growth and more prolific blooming. In regions with particularly hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. However, if grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. An ideal location for Iris domestica would be one with abundant morning sun and some protection during the harshest afternoon rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Iris domestica is fairly simple and primarily done to maintain the plant's appearance and health. After the flowers have bloomed and faded, it is advisable to deadhead the spent flowers to encourage further blooming and prevent seed formation, which can drain the plant's energy. In the fall, after the foliage has died back naturally, cut back the dead leaves to just above the ground. This helps prevent fungal diseases over the winter. Regular removal of dead or damaged foliage throughout the growing season is also beneficial."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Blackberry Lily","description":"Iris domestica, commonly known as leopard lily, blackberry lily, and leopard flower, is an ornamental plant in the Iridaceae family. In 2005, based on molecular DNA sequence evidence, Belamcanda chinensis, the sole species in the genus Belamcanda, was transferred to the genus Iris and renamed Iris domestica. Other synonyms are Epidendrum domesticum L., Vanilla domestica (L.) Druce, Belamcanda punctata Moench, Gemmingia chinensis (L.) Kuntze, Ixia chinensis L., Morea chinensis, and Pardanthus chinensis Ker Gawl.)","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["China","India","Japan"],"other_name":["Blackberry Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Iris domestica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17196,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pseudevernia furfuracea, commonly known as tree moss or lichen, does not require traditional watering like other houseplants since it extracts moisture from the air. To ensure it maintains its health, an environment with adequate humidity is vital. Mist the lichen lightly with water every couple of weeks or if the air feels particularly dry, especially during winter when indoor heating can reduce humidity significantly. Avoid soaking it, as too much moisture can cause it to decay. Observing the lichen regularly can help in adjusting the misting frequency based on ambient conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pseudevernia furfuracea thrives best in indirect sunlight or shaded areas, resembling its natural habitat usually found on tree bark in forests. Place it in a spot with bright, filtered light to mimic these conditions, avoiding direct sunlight as it can dry out and damage the lichen. A north or east-facing window works well where the light is softer, providing a more indirect intensity. Limiting exposure to full sun helps prevent drying out and desiccation, allowing it to extract moisture from the atmosphere more effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pseudevernia furfuracea is not typically required as it is not a fast-growing or traditional plant but a type of lichen. If desired, trim any parts that appear brittle or excessively dull to encourage new growth and maintain the lichen's aesthetic appeal. Use sharp scissors and cut at the base of any discolored or damaged sections. Handling the lichen gently to avoid causing damage to its structure is essential. Besides occasional aesthetic trimming, regular pruning is unnecessary as the lichen will maintain its form naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tree moss","description":"Pseudevernia furfuracea, commonly known as tree moss, is a lichenized species of fungus that grows on the bark of firs and pines. The lichen is rather sensitive to air pollution, its presence usually indicating good air conditions in the growing place. The species has numerous human uses, including use in perfume, embalming and in medicine. Large amounts of tree moss is annually processed in France for the perfume industry.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["tree moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Pseudevernia furfuracea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17494,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Kalmia procumbens, commonly known as alpine azalea, prefers moist but well-draining soil. It's important to maintain consistent moisture, especially during the growing season, but make sure the soil does not become waterlogged as this can damage the roots. In drier periods, or if grown indoors, water when the top inch of soil feels dry. Use rainwater or distilled water if possible, as Kalmia procumbens is sensitive to the high pH of tap water. Keeping a balanced moisture regime will encourage healthy growth and flowering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kalmia procumbens thrives in bright, indirect light to partial shade. It is ideally suited for alpine gardens or woodland settings where it can receive dappled sunlight. Full sun can be tolerated in cooler climates, but in hotter regions, too much direct sunlight can lead to leaf scorch or drying out. If you're growing it indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window to mimic its natural habitat. Ensuring it gets the right amount of light will help promote healthier foliage and more prolific blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kalmia procumbens is generally minimal, as it is a slow-growing ground cover. Light trimming post-flowering can help maintain its shape and encourage a denser growth habit. Always use clean, sharp pruners to prevent damage or disease. Remove any dead or diseased branches as soon as you notice them. In addition, pruning any leggy or overextended stems can help maintain the plant’s attractive, compact form. Pruning should be done in late spring or early summer after the plant has finished flowering."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"alpine azalea","description":"Kalmia procumbens, commonly known as alpine azalea or trailing azalea, is a dwarf shrub of high mountain regions of the Northern Hemisphere that usually grows no more than 10 centimeters (4 in) tall. This is typically done after the plant blooms and enters its dormant phase. Gently cut the dead flower spikes at the base and remove any yellowed or brown foliage to keep the plant tidy. Avoid cutting healthy leaves as these are essential for storing energy for the next growth cycle. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17592,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pseudorchis albida, also known as the Small White Orchid, prefers well-drained, moist soil. To properly water this plant, ensure the soil remains slightly damp, but not waterlogged. During its active growing season in spring and summer, water regularly to maintain soil moisture, but allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In the dormant autumn and winter months, reduce watering significantly. Avoid using hard water, and if possible, collect rainwater or use distilled water to maintain the correct pH balance and avoid mineral buildup."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This orchid species thrives in partial shade to full sun conditions, depending on its native environment of grasslands and open woods. Ideally, provide indirect sunlight or dappled shade for best results, simulating its natural habitat. Avoid placing it in direct, harsh sunlight, particularly during midday, as this can cause leaf scorch. If grown indoors, placing it near an east or west-facing window with filtered sunlight is ideal. During its flowering period, ensure it receives enough light to encourage blooming, adjusting lighting conditions as needed throughout the year."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pseudorchis albida is minimal but beneficial. After flowering in late summer, once the flower spike has wilted and the seeds have dispersed or if seed collection is not desired, cut the spike down to the base. This can help the plant conserve energy for the next growth cycle. Remove any dead or diseased leaves as they appear, and clear away debris to prevent pests. Be cautious not to cut back the rosette of leaves as it continues to photosynthesize and support the tuber below ground for the following season's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Small-white Orchid","description":"Pseudorchis is a monotypic genus of flowering plants from the orchid family, Orchidaceae. The sole species is the small white orchid (Pseudorchis albida). It is found across much of Europe and northern Asia from Spain and Iceland to Kamchatka, including France, Great Britain, Germany, Poland, Scandinavia, Ukraine and much of Russia. It also occurs in Greenland and eastern Canada (Quebec, Newfoundland & Labrador). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16894,"attracts":["Birds","Squirrels"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Quercus polymorpha, commonly known as the Monterrey oak or Mexican white oak, is a drought-tolerant tree that prefers a well-drained soil. After transplanting, it requires regular watering until established, typically for the first one or two growing seasons. Once established, it is very drought-resistant and should be watered deeply and infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering should be avoided, especially in clay soils, as it can lead to root rot. During prolonged dry spells, some additional deep watering may be beneficial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus polymorpha thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the tree should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain healthy growth rates and a dense canopy. However, it can adapt to areas with some afternoon shade, particularly in hotter climates, to protect it from intense heat stress. Providing adequate sunlight helps the tree develop a strong structure and deep green foliage. If planting near structures or other trees, allow for ample space as this oak species can grow to be quite expansive both in height and width."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Quercus polymorpha, or Mexican white oak, should generally be done during the dormant season in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This tree requires minimal pruning, but dead, damaged, or diseased branches should be removed to maintain its health and appearance. Additionally, any crossing or inward-growing branches should be pruned out to encourage a strong, open structure. Be cautious not to remove more than one-third of the tree’s canopy at a time to prevent stress. Pruning mature oaks requires care to avoid pest and disease issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican White Oak","description":"Quercus polymorpha, the Mexican white oak, Monterrey oak or netleaf white oak, is a North American species of oak. It is widespread in Mexico, Guatemala, and Honduras, and known from a single population in the United States (about 30 km north of the Río Grande in Val Verde County, Texas) but widely planted as an ornamental.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Mexican White Oak"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Quercus polymorpha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Conversely, too much direct sunlight might cause the leaves to bleach, so it's crucial to balance the exposure according to the plant's response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia prostrata is typically not necessary as the plant naturally maintains a low, spreading form. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16202,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cladium mariscus, commonly known as fen-sedge, typically thrives in wetlands or areas with moisture-retentive soil. When cultivating Cladium mariscus, ensure that the soil remains consistently moist, especially during the growing season. It can tolerate waterlogged conditions and should be watered frequently to emulate its natural habitat. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this can stress the plant. In drier seasons or indoor settings, increase the frequency of watering to maintain soil moisture, but ensure good drainage to prevent stagnant water, which can harm the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cladium mariscus prefers full sun to partial shade, thriving under bright conditions that mimic its natural wetland habitat. Ideally, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and health. If planted in a shadier spot, ensure it receives dappled sunlight to allow for proper metabolic function. In overly bright conditions, some protection from intense afternoon sun can help prevent leaf scorch, especially in hotter climates. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window to maximize sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cladium mariscus mainly involves removing dead or damaged leaves to promote healthy growth. This can be done during the growing season, typically in spring or early summer, when the plant is actively growing. Use clean, sharp shears to cut back any brown or dried foliage at the base. If the plant grows too large or dense, it can be thinned out to prevent overcrowding and encourage air circulation around the stems. Regularly check the plant for any signs of disease or pests, removing affected parts immediately to prevent spreading."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Swamp Sawgrass","description":"Cladium mariscus is a species of flowering plant in the sedge family known by the common names swamp sawgrass, great fen-sedge, saw-sedge or sawtooth sedge. It can be up to 2.5 metres (8 ft 2 in) tall, and has leaves with hard serrated edges.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["Swamp Sawgrass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cladium mariscus"],"soil":["Wet","Peaty","Muddy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

You can trim back stems that become leggy or remove any dead or damaged leaves. Pruning is best done during the growing season in the spring and summer. Use sharp, clean scissors or gardening shears to cut the stems just above a node to encourage new growth. Pinching back the tips of the stems can also promote a fuller appearance. Regular pruning also helps in managing the plant's size and keeps it looking neat and vibrant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Zigzag Spiderwort","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Zigzag Spiderwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Tradescantia subaspera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17685,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Scilla peruviana prefers well-drained soil and should be watered regularly, especially during its growing season in the autumn and spring. However, it is crucial to avoid overwatering, as this can lead to bulb rot. The soil should be allowed to dry out slightly between waterings. In the summer, when the plant enters dormancy, reduce watering significantly. Ensure that the planting medium is not waterlogged and pots have sufficient drainage holes to prevent excess moisture accumulation. Monitor the plant's environment to adjust watering frequency depending on climate conditions, ensuring the soil remains just moist enough to sustain its bulbs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scilla peruviana thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive several hours of sunlight each day, particularly in the morning, to promote healthy growth and vibrant blooms. However, in regions with very intense sunlight, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. In cooler climates, more sunlight is typically better to support robust development. When planting, choose a location where the plant can bask in sufficient sunlight while also being protected from harsh midday rays. Adjust its position according to seasonal sun changes to optimize light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Scilla peruviana is quite straightforward. After the flowering period, it's essential to remove spent flowers to prevent the plant from putting energy into seed production, instead directing it towards strengthening the bulb for the following year. The foliage should be left to die back naturally, as the leaves are crucial for photosynthesis and for storing energy in the bulb. Once the leaves have withered and turned yellow, they can be trimmed back to ground level. Avoid cutting green, healthy leaves, as this may negatively impact the plant's future blooming potential."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Portuguese squill","description":"Scilla peruviana, the Portuguese squill, is a species of Scilla native to the western Mediterranean region in Iberia, Italy, and northwest Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean region","Portugal","Spain","Italy","North Africa"],"other_name":["Portuguese squill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Scilla peruviana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17287,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Corokia buddleioides prefers well-drained soil and should be watered moderately. Ensure the soil is completely dry before watering again to avoid over-watering, which can lead to root rot. In the growing season, from spring to summer, water the plant more frequently to support its growth. During fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down. A good practice is to water deeply but less frequently, allowing the water to reach the roots and encouraging deep root growth. Always check the top few inches of soil for dryness before watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Corokia buddleioides thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and stress. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright window but avoid direct sunlight exposure that may be too harsh. Adequate sunlight helps the plant develop its characteristic twisted and contorted foliage, while insufficient light may result in leggy growth and fewer flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Corokia buddleioides is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches using sharp, clean pruning shears. This plant can also be shaped into a hedge or a more compact form by trimming back the outer growth. Light pruning throughout the growing season can help maintain its desired shape. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Korokio","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Korokio"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Corokia buddleioides"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During dry spells, you might need to water occasionally but ensure that the plant has proper drainage to prevent waterlogging. In areas with natural rainfall that meets the plant's needs, additional watering may not be necessary at all."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hudsonia ericoides thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to flourish. It is well-suited to open, coastal, or sandy areas where it naturally receives abundant light throughout the day. Full sun exposure helps maintain its compact growth and encourages robust flowering. Although it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade can lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. Ensure it is planted in a location where it won't be shaded out by taller plants or structures to ensure optimal health and flower production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hudsonia ericoides is generally minimal but can be done to keep the plant tidy and encourage new growth. After the flowering season, which typically occurs in late spring, deadhead any spent flowers to promote a more aesthetically pleasing appearance. Remove any dead or diseased stems to maintain plant health. Light pruning can also help maintain the desired shape of the plant, as overgrown branches can be trimmed back gently. However, ensure not to cut into old wood, as this can hinder the plant's blooming capabilities."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pine barren goldenheather","description":"Hudsonia ericoides is a species of flowering plant in the rock-rose family known by the common names pine barren goldenheather, false heather, and golden-heather. However, adequate drainage should be ensured to avoid root rot, which can be a risk if water does not properly drain away."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lachnanthes caroliniana thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, providing it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day will ensure robust growth and encourage flowering. When grown in less sunny areas, the plant may become leggy and won't flower as prolifically. Mimicking its natural habitat conditions by ensuring a bright, sunny environment will contribute significantly to the plant's vibrant and healthy appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lachnanthes caroliniana is minimal but can be beneficial for maintaining plant health and appearance. Additionally, any old or spent flower stems can be cut back to supporting fresh flowering and tidy up the plant's appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent pathogen transmission. Regular monitoring ensures the best health and vigor for the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina Redroot","description":"Lachnanthes is a genus of monocotyledonous plants in the bloodwort family containing only one species, i.e., Lachnanthes caroliniana, commonly known as Carolina redroot or bloodroot. The plant is native to eastern North America, from southeastern Nova Scotia (especially the Molega Lake area) and Massachusetts in the north, south to Florida and Cuba, and west along the Gulf of Mexico to Louisiana. It has also been reported from an island in the western Caribbean off the coast...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["Carolina Redroot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Lachnanthes caroliniana"],"soil":["Wet","Peaty","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Since the plant produces a milky, latex sap when cut, which can be irritating to skin and eyes, wearing gloves and protective eyewear is recommended during the process. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during the growing season, which spans from spring to early summer. However, you should ensure that the soil is well-draining to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent overwatering. During dormant periods in the winter, you can reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sisyrinchium micranthum thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight a day. Deadheading, or cutting off the faded flowers, will encourage the plant to put energy into producing more blooms rather than seed production. In early spring, consider a light trim to remove any old growth from the previous year, which will encourage new shoots and maintain a tidy appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Blue Pigroot","description":"Sisyrinchium micranthum, commonly known as blue pigroot or striped rush-leaf, is a grass-like species in the iris family, Iridaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17686,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Scilla luciliae, commonly known as glory-of-the-snow, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered moderately. During its growing season in the spring, ensure the soil is kept moist but not waterlogged. Watering should be reduced later in the season as the plant dies back and enters dormancy. It’s essential to avoid overwatering, especially in areas with high humidity, as this can lead to bulb rot. Always check the soil before watering; it should be allowed to dry out slightly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scilla luciliae thrives in full sun to partial shade. During its active growth period in early spring, it benefits from full sunlight, especially in regions where other trees and plants may not have fully leafed out, allowing the plant ample access to light. In areas with hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect it from intense sun. Ensure the planting location offers at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal blooming. After blooming, as the plant enters dormancy, sunlight requirements become less critical."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Scilla luciliae is minimal and generally involves removing spent flowers to prevent unwanted self-seeding and to encourage the plant's energy to go back into the bulb for the next flowering season. When the flowers have faded, you can snip off the flower stalks. However, allow the foliage to die back naturally, as it is crucial for photosynthesis and storing nutrients back into the bulb. Do not cut the leaves while they are still green; they should be left until they turn yellow and wither away naturally."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Boissier's Glory-of-the-snow","description":"Chionodoxa luciliae (syn. C. gigantea), the Bossier's glory-of-the-snow or Lucile's glory-of-the-snow, is a bulbous perennial from west Turkey flowering in early spring. After flowering, it goes into dormancy until the next spring. The Latin name is in honour of Lucile, the wife of the Swiss botanist Pierre Edmond Boissier.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Turkey"],"other_name":["Boissier's Glory-of-the-snow"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulbs"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Scilla luciliae"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17096,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tradescantia zebrina prefers moderately moist soil, so water it when the top inch of soil feels dry. During the growth period in spring and summer, regular watering is required, but avoid soggy conditions as they can lead to root rot. In the cooler months of fall and winter, reduce watering and ensure that the plant dries out a little more between waterings. Always check the soil moisture before watering and adjust your schedule based on humidity and temperature conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tradescantia zebrina thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate lower light levels. Place the plant near a window where it can receive filtered sunlight for several hours a day. Too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, leading to discoloration, while too little light can cause the plant to become leggy and lose its vibrant colors. If grown indoors, rotating the plant regularly can help ensure even growth by allowing all sides to receive adequate light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tradescantia zebrina helps maintain its vibrant appearance and control its growth. Regularly pinch back the stem tips to encourage bushier growth and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. Trim back any dead or damaged leaves to keep the plant healthy. If the stems become too long, you can cut them back to maintain the desired shape. Use clean, sharp scissors to make clean cuts, which can also encourage new growth along the cut stems."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"inchplant","description":"Tradescantia zebrina, formerly known as Zebrina pendula, is a species of spiderwort more commonly known as an inchplant or wandering jew. The common name is shared with closely related varieties T. fluminensis and T. pallida. Tradescantia zebrina is native to Mexico, Central America and Colombia, and naturalized in parts of Asia, Africa, Australia, South America, and various oceanic islands.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green, purple, and silver"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["inchplant"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Tradescantia zebrina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18075,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spiranthes sinensis requires consistent moisture to thrive, but it is crucial to avoid waterlogging. The soil should be well-draining yet retain some moisture to simulate its natural habitat. Water the plant regularly during the growing season, keeping the soil evenly moist. However, reduce watering slightly in the dormant period, allowing the top layer to dry out between waterings. Adjust frequency based on the temperature and humidity levels in your environment. Be cautious of root rot, which can occur if the plant is left sitting in water for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiranthes sinensis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct exposure to strong sunlight can scorch the leaves, so it’s crucial to provide a filtered light environment, such as near an east or west-facing window that receives some morning or late afternoon sun. If you are growing this plant outdoors, consider placing it in a location that receives dappled light or partial shade. Adequate lighting is essential for flowering; however, too much or too little light can impede growth, so finding a balanced exposure is key to keeping your Spiranthes healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Spiranthes sinensis is relatively straightforward. After the flowering period, it is advisable to remove the spent flower spikes to encourage the plant to focus energy on growth rather than seed production. Trim any dead or yellowing leaves regularly to maintain a tidy appearance. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make cuts to prevent the spread of disease. While pruning is minimal, it is essential to avoid excessive cutting, as orchids respond better to light, targeted pruning than heavy modifications."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese Spiranthes","description":"Spiranthes sinensis, commonly known as the Chinese spiranthes, is a species of orchid occurring in eastern and southeastern Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia"],"other_name":["Chinese Spiranthes"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal infections"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Spiranthes sinensis"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16596,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lophophora williamsii, commonly known as peyote, prefers infrequent watering, reflecting its native arid environments. Water sparingly and allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growth period from spring to early autumn, watering can be moderate—approximately once every three to four weeks. In winter, reduce watering drastically or stop altogether to mimic natural dormancy conditions, preventing root rot. Always use a container with drainage holes and a well-draining cactus mix to ensure excess water doesn't accumulate, as the plant is highly susceptible to over-watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lophophora williamsii thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, mimicking the desert environment where it naturally occurs. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, particularly during morning or late afternoon, but harsh midday sun can scorch the plant. Ideally, this cactus should be placed near a south or east-facing window. If grown outdoors in suitable climates, provide it some shade during the hottest part of the day. For indoor cultivation, using grow lights during the winter months can help compensate for reduced natural light, encouraging healthy growth year-round."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lophophora williamsii is generally not necessary as it naturally maintains a compact shape. However, if there are damaged or diseased parts, these can be carefully removed with clean, sharp tools. Take care not to over-prune, as removing too much can stress the cactus. Removing pups or offsets can be done to control size or propagate new plants, but it's important to let any cut areas dry out completely before watering to prevent infection. Pruning can be done at any time, although the plant may respond best during its active growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Peyote","description":"Lophophora williamsii /loʊˈfɒfərə wɪlˈjæmsiaɪ/ or peyote (/pəˈjoʊti/) is a small, spineless cactus with psychoactive alkaloids, particularly mescaline. The English common name peyote is a Spanish loanword, which comes from the Nahuatl name peyōtl , said to be derived from a root meaning \"glisten\" or \"glistening\". Other sources translate the Nahuatl word as \"Divine Messenger\". Native North Americans are likely to have used peyote, often for spiritual purposes, for at least 5,500 years.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Peyote"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lophophora williamsii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid any damage or infection to the plant."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Madagascar Ragwort","description":"Senecio madagascariensis also known as Madagascar ragwort is a species of the genus Senecio and family Asteraceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16395,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eurybia sibirica, also known as the Siberian aster, prefers consistent moisture but does not like to be in soggy soil. Water the plant moderately, ensuring that the top inch of soil dries out before watering again. During hot summer months, you may need to water more frequently to prevent the plant from drying out. In contrast, during cooler months or in shaded conditions, reduce watering to prevent over-saturation. Always aim for a balance that keeps the soil moist but not waterlogged to promote healthy root development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eurybia sibirica thrives in locations with full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to support optimal growth and flowering. However, in regions with intense summer heat, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching and help maintain moisture levels in the soil. When planting in a garden, choose a spot that receives morning sun and some protection from the harsher afternoon rays, especially in hotter climates. Adjust exposure based on geographical location to match the plant's sunlight needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Eurybia sibirica is relatively straightforward and helps maintain the plant's shape and encourage robust blooming. It is recommended to deadhead spent flowers throughout the blooming season to promote further flowers and prevent the plant from directing energy into seed production. At the end of the growing season, usually in late autumn, cut back the stems to about half their height. This not only tidies the plant but also helps it prepare for the winter dormancy. Regularly remove any dead or damaged leaves to maintain overall plant health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Siberian Aster","description":"Eurybia sibirica, commonly known as the Siberian aster or arctic aster, is an herbaceous perennial native to north western North America and northern Eurasia. It is found largely in open areas of subarctic boreal forests, though it is also found in a wide variety of habitats in the region. It is similar in appearance to Eurybia merita, but their ranges overlap only near the border between the US and Canada, where E. sibirica is generally found...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Asia"],"other_name":["Siberian Aster"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Eurybia sibirica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17496,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lamium galeobdolon, commonly known as Yellow Archangel, prefers evenly moist soil but can tolerate some dryness once established. It's important to water the plant consistently, especially during prolonged dry periods. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, particularly if the plant is in a shaded area where evaporation is slower. During hot or dry spells, increase the frequency of watering, but avoid waterlogging. When grown in containers, check the soil moisture more frequently as potting soil dries out faster than garden beds."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lamium galeobdolon thrives in partial to full shade conditions. It can tolerate a few hours of direct morning sunlight, but too much sun, especially intense afternoon sun, can scorch the leaves and stunt growth. In shaded areas, it performs well as a ground cover, spreading easily without the risk of sunburn. However, in dappled sun or light shade conditions, the variegation of the leaves is more pronounced. If planted in too much shade, it may become leggy or invasive as it reaches for light. Adjust sunlight exposure based on the plant's response, ensuring it remains healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lamium galeobdolon is essential to maintain shape and promote healthy growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Trim back any dead or damaged stems and remove faded flowers to encourage more blooms. If the plant becomes too unruly or invasive, cutting it back after flowering can help keep it under control. Regularly check for any dead or browning leaves and remove them to improve air circulation, which can help in preventing diseases such as powdery mildew. Pruning also aids in keeping the plant lush and compact."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"yellow archangel","description":"Lamium galeobdolon, commonly known as yellow archangel, artillery plant, or aluminium plant, is a widespread wildflower in Europe, and has been introduced elsewhere as a garden plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17792,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Catasetum integerrimum, like many orchids, requires a distinctive watering approach due to its growth pattern. During the growing season, typically spring to late summer, water the plant generously and frequently to keep the medium moist, but not waterlogged. As the plant enters its dormancy in the fall, gradually reduce watering. In the dormant period over the winter months, reduce watering further, allowing the potting medium to dry out between waterings. Resume regular watering as new growth appears in spring. Using rainwater or distilled water is preferred to avoid mineral build-up that can damage the plant roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Catasetum integerrimum thrives in bright, indirect light. During the growing season, it benefits from receiving plenty of light, ideally around 50% shade, similar to conditions found under a canopy in its native habitat. This means a position with morning sun or filtered light throughout the day is optimal. Avoid direct midday sun, which can scorch the leaves, especially if the plant is not acclimated to intense sunlight. During its dormancy period, reduced light is acceptable, as the plant has fewer energy requirements. Adjust the plant's exposure based on seasonal sunlight variations and growth phases to promote robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Catasetum integerrimum primarily involves cutting back flower spikes once they have finished blooming, as they won't rebloom and removing them helps conserve the plant's energy for new growth. If any leaves become yellow or diseased, remove them carefully to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of infection. Avoid trimming healthy roots as they are crucial for the plant’s nutrient absorption. After the plant enters dormancy and all leaves have naturally shriveled and fallen, you can clean up dead material from the pseudobulbs to maintain aesthetic appeal and ensure healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spurred Catasetum","description":"The Intact Catasetum (Catasetum integerrimum) is a species of orchid found from Mexico to Central America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Spurred Catasetum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Catasetum integerrimum"],"soil":["Loose","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, newly planted or young Quercus sinuata trees benefit from regular watering to promote healthy establishment in the first growing season. Ideally, water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings to encourage deep root growth. Avoid waterlogging as this can lead to root rot or other diseases. As the tree matures, it should rely mostly on natural rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus sinuata thrives in areas with full sun exposure, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to grow optimally. It can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but its growth will be slower and less vigorous compared to when it receives more sunlight. When planting, ensure the site is well-drained and open enough to provide ample sunlight access throughout the day. Adequate sunlight is crucial for photosynthesis, promoting healthy foliage and robust growth, which contributes to the tree's overall strength and adaptability in various environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Quercus sinuata is necessary to maintain a healthy and aesthetically pleasing form. The best time to prune is during the dormant season, late winter to early spring, before new growth begins. Remove dead, diseased, or damaged branches to improve overall tree health and ensure good air circulation. Young trees benefit from formative pruning to establish a strong, central leader and eliminate any crossing branches. Regularly inspect the tree for any signs of disease or pests and prune as needed to prevent their spread. Avoid heavy pruning in a single session to not stress the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bastard oak","description":"Quercus sinuata, the bastard oak, bastard white oak, or Durand oak, is a North American species of oak. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. When grown indoors as an ornamental, position near a south or west-facing window. In areas with harsh winters, consider providing some protection from frost as the plant is only moderately cold-hardy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Citrus trifoliata is important to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It's best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead or diseased branches first, followed by any crossing or rubbing branches that may lead to damage. Trim back any overly long shoots to maintain a compact shape. Pruning also helps increase air circulation, reducing the risk of pests and diseases. Be cautious of the plant's sharp spines while pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"trifoliate orange","description":"The trifoliate orange, Citrus trifoliata or Poncirus trifoliata, is a member of the family Rutaceae in the Citrus genus. The species is unusual in Citrus for having deciduous, compound leaves and pubescent (downy) fruit.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Dark Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Korea"],"other_name":["trifoliate orange"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Citrus trifoliata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade is beneficial to prevent the foliage from scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clematis alpina is relatively straightforward. Remove any dead, damaged, or weak stems to promote healthy growth and enhance flowering for the next season. Be cautious not to prune too drastically unless necessary, as this can reduce the number of flowers. Light pruning helps maintain the plant’s shape and encourages a bushier growth. Remember that Clematis alpina generally needs only minimal pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alpine Clematis","description":"Clematis alpina or Alpine clematis is a flowering deciduous vine of the genus Clematis. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18076,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Adiantum aethiopicum, commonly known as the Common Maidenhair Fern, prefers consistently moist soil. Water it regularly to keep the soil evenly damp but not waterlogged, as it can be susceptible to root rot. It's crucial to avoid letting the soil dry out completely between waterings. Increasing humidity by placing a tray of water nearby or misting the leaves can also be beneficial, especially in arid environments or during indoor heating. Ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent water accumulation at the bottom."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Common Maidenhair Fern thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, making it ideal for locations with filtered light or partial shade. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the delicate fronds, turning them brown. When grown indoors, place it near a window with filtered light or a few feet away from a bright light source. If the light is too intense, use a sheer curtain to diffuse it. In low light conditions, the plant may not grow as vigorously, so balanced lighting is key for its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Adiantum aethiopicum is mainly about removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage new growth and maintain the plant's aesthetic appeal. Regularly inspect the plant and snip off any brown or dry foliage at the base using clean, sharp scissors. This not only keeps the plant tidy but also helps direct energy to healthier parts of the fern. If the plant becomes too large, you can also trim back some of the older fronds without harming the plant. However, avoid extensive pruning as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common maidenhair fern","description":"Adiantum aethiopicum, also known as the common maidenhair fern, is a small fern of widespread distribution. Occurring in Africa, Australia, Norfolk Island and New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","New Zealand","Africa","New Guinea"],"other_name":["common maidenhair fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Division","Spores"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Adiantum aethiopicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
